Financial disclosure forms shall be filed by the town attorney, the town manager, the chief of police, the clerk/treasurer, the members of town council and the mayor. In addition, all future officers or employees who have a personal interest in any transaction before the government agency of which he is an officer or employee shall file a disclosure of such interest. 
(Code 1973, § 2-21) 
Sec. 2-73. - Bonuses for employees. 
    At such times, and in such amounts, as are properly budgeted for, the Farmville Town Council may, by resolution, provide for monetary bonuses to its officers and employees. 
(Ord. No. 2-2015 , 4-8-2015) 
Secs. 2-74-2-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AFFIRMATIVE ACTION PLAN 

Sec. 2-91. - Nondiscrimination policy. 
(a)  In compliance with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, it is the policy of the town: 
(1)  To provide equality of opportunity in employment with the town for all persons. 
(2)  To carry out all programs and activities in compliance with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and in such a manner that no person shall, on the grounds of race, color, national origin, religion, age, handicap or sex, be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination with respect to any such programs or activities. 
(3)  To afford full and fair representation of all sectors of the population within the corporate limits of the town. 
(b)  To effectuate its nondiscrimination policy, the town adopts this affirmative action program. 
Sec. 2-92. - Employment and personnel practices. 
    It is the policy of the town to prohibit discrimination because of race, color, national origin, religion, age, handicap or sex in all aspects of its personnel policies, programs, practices and operations, and in all its working conditions and relationships with employees and applicants for employment; and to promote the full realization of equal opportunity in employment through continuing programs of affirmative action in the town. 
Sec. 2-93. - Affirmative action program. 
    The town manager shall direct the implementation of this affirmative action program to promote equal opportunity in every aspect of employment policy and practice, including but not limited to: employment, upgrading, demotion or transfer, recruitment or recruitment advertising; layoff or termination; rates of pay or other forms of compensation; and selection of training, including apprenticeship. This implementation shall include, but not be limited to, the following actions: 
(1)  A notice of the town's policy on nondiscrimination in employment shall be posted in a conspicuous place, so as to come to the attention of all town employees and applicants for employment. 
(2)  Notification of employment opportunities, new positions, vacancies, promotion possibilities and training opportunities shall be posted in a conspicuous place, so as to come to the attention of all town employees and applicants for employment. 
(3)  Newspaper advertisements and other public announcements of employment opportunities placed by or on behalf of the town shall state that the town is an equal opportunity employer. 
(4)  The town manager shall make an annual assessment of the town employment. This assessment shall include an equal opportunity strategy outlining the specific equal opportunity actions to be taken by the town during the upcoming fiscal year. 
Sec. 2-94. - Personnel for implementing equal opportunity policy. 
(a)  Equal opportunity review board. The town designates the town council as the town's equal opportunity review board (EOR board). In all cases involving employment actions, the decision of such EOR board, upon review of proceedings carried out in accord with the procedures established by this section, shall be final. 
(b)  Equal opportunity counselor. The town council shall designate an equal opportunity counselor. The town manager shall not hold this position. It shall be the duty of such counselor to provide advice to employees, or other persons, concerning their rights under the equal opportunity policy established in section 2-91, and other pertinent laws and regulations; to conduct initial investigations as provided in this section; and to seed conciliation of such complaints with the appropriate town officials. 
(c)  Equal opportunity hearing officer. In appropriate cases, the equal opportunity review board shall designate a disinterested person to conduct formal investigations and hearing on complaints of discrimination brought in the manner provided in this section. 
(d)  Display of names. The name of the equal opportunity counselor and hearing officer shall be posted in conspicuous places. 
Sec. 2-95. - Procedures for conciliation, investigation and resolution of complaints of discrimination. 
(a)  Any person who believes that he has been discriminated against by reason of race, color, religion, sex, age, creed, handicap or national origin, in connection with any personnel action taken by or under the authority of the town, shall have the right to seek advice and conciliation through the equal opportunity counselor. 
(b)  The steps to be followed in processing a grievance shall be outlined in the town's grievance procedure. 
Sec. 2-96. - Contractors. 
    Contractors of the town shall comply with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. 
Sec. 2-97. - Operation practices. 
    It is the policy of the town to provide equal access to all persons, regardless of race, color, religion, age, handicap, sex or national origin, to all aspects of all its operations, including organization and administration. 
Sec. 2-98. - Procedures. 
(a)  Any person who believes that he has been discriminated against by reason of race, color, religion, age, handicap, sex or national origin, in connection with the administration of the town, shall be advised of his right to seek advice and conciliation through the equal opportunity counselor. 
(b)  The aggrieved party shall submit his complaint in writing to the equal opportunity counselor. 
(c)  Thereafter, the procedure shall be the same as set forth in the grievance procedures. 
Chapter 3 - ADVERTISING[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Cable television, Ch. 7; junkyards, car lots and automobile graveyards, Ch. 13; licenses and permits, Ch. 14; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 19; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 23; taxicabs, Ch. 26; trees and shrubs, Ch. 27; advertisements on fences around junkyard, car lot or automobile graveyard, § 13-6; scattering handbills on streets and sidewalks, § 23-12. 

Sec. 3-1. - Posting advertisements, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, write, print, stamp, nail or affix to any building, erection, fence, tree, lamppost, sidewalk, telephone, telegraph or other pole or to any other improvement any poster, showbill, handbill or other printed notice or sign without a permit from the town manager. 
(Code 1973, § 3-1) 
Sec. 3-2. - Tearing down authorized advertisements or posters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tear down any advertisement or poster put up with the consent of the owner of the property whereupon the same is posted, or to alter or mutilate the same. 
(Code 1973, § 3-2) 
Sec. 3-3. - Permit prerequisite to distribution of handbills, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or hand out any handbills, circulars or other advertising matter without first having secured a permit therefor from the town manager. 
(Code 1973, § 3-3) 
Sec. 3-4. - Standards for issuance of permit. 
    Permits under this chapter shall be issued when consistent with the health, safety and welfare of the town's inhabitants. 
Chapter 4 - AIRPORT[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 12; licenses and permits, Ch. 14; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15; taxicabs, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Authority of town to acquire, construct, maintain and operate airports, Code of Virginia, § 5.1-31. 

Sec. 4-1. - Name. 
    The airport owned by the town and located approximately three (3) miles northwest of town in Cumberland County, Virginia, is named and shall be known as the Farmville Regional Airport. 
(Code 1973, § 4-1; Ord. No. 83, 5-12-2004) 
Sec. 4-2. - General supervision and control. 
    The general supervision and control of the Farmville Municipal Airport shall be vested in the town manager, and he shall be in charge of all work done therein. It shall be his duty to see that the landing strip, turnarounds, taxiways, apron, grounds, fences, buildings and facilities are kept in good condition, and he shall report their condition and needs to the town council. 
(Code 1973, § 4-2) 
State Law reference- Operation of airport by special officer, Code of Virginia, § 5.1-41. 
Sec. 4-3. - Trespassing at night. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon the Farmville Municipal Airport property during the hours of darkness without permission of the town manager or the custodian of the airport for any purpose other than law enforcement, town business or service or flying of aircraft. 
(Code 1973, § 4-3) 
Sec. 4-4. - Hunting; discharge of firearms generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt or discharge firearms within the enclosure of the Farmville Municipal Airport property without written permission of the town manager; except, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to impede or prohibit any law enforcement officer in the normal performance of his duty. Violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 4-4) 
Editor's note- Because of the restrictions in Code of Virginia, § 15.1-29.15, the above section has not been revised. 
Cross reference- Discharge of firearms in cemetery, § 8-19; discharge of firearms generally, § 18-47. 
Sec. 4-5. - Operation of vehicles-Limited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate or ride any bicycle, motorcycle, automobile, truck, tractor or any other type of vehicle or conveyance except aircraft on the landing strip, turnarounds, taxiways, apron or grassed areas of the Farmville Municipal Airport except for maintenance purposes or for movement and service of aircraft under the supervision of the custodian, town manager or a designated agent of the town. Violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 4-5) 
Sec. 4-6. - Same-Regulations. 
    The streets and parking lots on the Farmville Municipal Airport property are hereby declared to be within the meaning of the term "highway" as that word is used and defined in section 1-2. The operation and use of vehicles on the streets and parking lots shall comply with and be subject to the traffic laws of the commonwealth. 
(Code 1973, § 4-6) 
Sec. 4-7. - Use of apron. 
    The apron between the taxiways and the hangars and administration building may be used only for loading and unloading passengers, freight and mail from airplanes or service to airplanes. Airplanes shall not be parked or left unattended on the apron except in the tie-down area. 
(Code 1973, § 4-7) 
Sec. 4-8. - Regulations generally. 
    Any person operating or using or visiting the Farmville Regional Airport shall conform and be bound by the following regulations: 
(1)  All persons and aircraft operating on or from the airport shall be subject to and bound by the rules and regulations adopted by the Federal Aviation Administration and the rules and regulations established by the state aviation board, pursuant to the Code of Virginia § 5.1. Such rules are hereby specifically adopted by reference and expressly made a part hereof as fully as if the same were completely. 
(2)  Violations of these regulations shall constitute a breach of duty causing a legal liability therefor. 
(3)  All persons using in any way the airport area shall exercise due care to guard against fire and injury to persons or property. No rubbish shall be scattered about the airport area and the crew of all visiting aircraft shall be required to keep clean the space allotted. 
(4)  No landing fee shall be collected by any person for the privilege of landing aircraft on the airport, the port being an "open port." 
(5)  Fees charged for storage of aircraft, service, etc. shall be posted. 
(6)  All landings and take-offs shall be made on the runways provided therefor. 
(7)  Unhoused aircraft must be parked in the space allotted and tied down at all times when the owner, the operator or his mechanic is not in attendance. 
(8)  No plane shall remain on the runways longer than is absolutely necessary in flying operations. The runways shall be kept clear of obstructions to planes at all times, and the runways shall be used solely for the landing and taking off of airplanes. 
(9)  All pilots landing on the field shall report immediately to the administrative office of the airport to register their names, addresses, types of equipment, license or military number of aircraft, its ownership, the time of their arrival, expected time of departure, service required and such other information as may be required for record purposes. 
(10)  It shall be the duty of every pilot, mechanic or other person employed at the airport, and they are authorized, to carry out these rules and to see that the general public uses due care and caution to prevent injury to themselves and other persons or property, and further, to preserve and protect the property and equipment of whatever nature on the field. 
(11)  It shall be the duty of the party in charge of operating the airport to immediately notify the director of public works of any defect in the condition of the airport for flying purposes. Any failure to so report any such defect until after an accident has been caused thereby shall be an omission of duty on the part of the party in charge of operating the airport. 
(12)  Notice is given that the airport is being operated under a license agreement also granting the privilege of local commercial flying for hire over which operation and commercial flying the town exercises no control, and all pilots of visiting planes, passenger and commercial flyers, operators and all persons visiting or flying in or from or using or operating the airport thereby agree to release the town from any and all responsibility incident to the manner in which the airport or landing field is operated and served from within or used from without. 
(13)  Landings and takeoffs shall be made, when practical, into the wind. 
(14)  A plane taxiing before taking off or after landing shall taxi on the right side of the runway according to the direction in which he is progressing, in order that sufficient space be allowed for the takeoff and landing of other aircraft. 
(15)  These rules and regulations shall be posted in conspicuous places to fully notify all persons of the terms and conditions upon which the airport is open. 
(Code 1973, § 4-8; Ord. No. 84, 5-12-2004) 
State Law reference- Airport rules and regulations, fees and charges, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-44. 
Sec. 4-9. - Records. 
    Proper records shall be kept by the custodian of the airport's operation, which records shall be open to inspection by the town council at all reasonable times. A complete report shall be made to the town council annually. 
(Code 1973, § 4-9) 
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 61, adopted Dec. 12, 2002 amended and re-enacted the former Ch. 5 and enacted a new Ch. 5 as set out herein. The former Ch. 5 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1973, §§ 5-1-5-21; Ord. No. 54, adopted Nov. 10, 1999. To preserve the numbering system of the Code and to facilitate indexing and reference the editor has redesignated §§ 5-1-5-32 as §§ 5-1-5-9, 5-39-5-47, 5-68-5-71, 5-92, 5-93, 5-124-5-127, 5-148-5-151, 5-172. 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15; noise control, Ch. 16; nuisances, Ch. 17; zoning, Ch. 29. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Purpose; legislative authority. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to provide for the regulation of dogs, or other animals and fowl, in the town and to prescribe penalties for its violation. 
(b)  This article is adopted under the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.84 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-2. - Definition. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal warden means any animal warden and any deputy animal warden duly appointed by the town manager and/or town council. 
    Livestock includes all domestic or domesticated bovine animals; equine animals, ovine animals; porcine animals, cervidae animals, capradae animals; animals of the genus Lama; ratites; fish or shellfish in aquaculture facilities, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 3.1-73.6; enclosed domesticated rabbits or hares raised for human food or fiber; or any other individual animal specifically raised for food or fiber, except companion animals. 
    Other officer includes all other persons employed by the people of Virginia or by any municipality, county or incorporated town thereof, whose duty it is to preserve the peace, to make arrests or to enforce the law. 
    Owner includes any person having a right or property in a dog; any person who keeps or harbors a dog, has it in his care, or acts as its custodian; and any person who permits a dog to remain on or about any premises occupied by him. 
    Poultry includes all domestic fowl and game birds raised in captivity. 
    Treasurer includes the treasurer of this town or other officer designated by law to collect taxes in this town and his assistants. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-3. - Duties of animal warden. 
    The animal warden shall discharge the duties provided for in Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.66 et seq., and such other duties as are provided in this article. The animal warden or deputy animal warden shall be appointed by the town manager and/or town council and under the supervision of the chief of police. The animal warden and assistants shall discharge their duties as outlined in Section 5 of the Town Code and other duties as provided in [Code of Virginia, §] 3.1-796.105. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-4. - Running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any dog, belonging to him or under his control, to run at large in the town at any time. 
(b)  Or the purpose of this section, a dog shall be deemed to run at large while roaming, running or self-hunting off the property of its owner or custodian and not under its owner's or custodian's immediate control. Any person who permits his dog to run at large, or remain unconfined, unrestricted and not penned up during the period specified in subsection (a) of this section shall be deemed to have violated the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor and shall be subject to punishment as provided in Code of Virginia, §§ 3.1-796.93 and 3.1-796.128. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-5. - Dogs killing, injuring or chasing livestock or poultry. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any animal warden or other officer who may find a dog in the act of killing or injuring livestock or poultry to kill such dog forthwith whether such dog bears a tag or not. Any person finding a dog committing any of the depredations mentioned in this section shall have the right to kill such dog on sight as shall any owner of livestock or his agent finding a dog chasing livestock on land utilized by the livestock when the circumstances show that such chasing is harmful to the livestock. Any court shall have the power to order the animal warden or other officer to kill any dog known to be a confirmed livestock or poultry killer; and any dog killing poultry for the third time shall be considered a confirmed poultry killer. The court, through its contempt powers, may compel the owner, custodian, or harborer of the dog to produce the dog. 
(b)  Any animal warden who has reason to believe that any dog is killing livestock or poultry shall be empowered to seize such dog solely for the purpose of examining such dog in order to determine whether it committed any of the depredations mentioned in this section. Any animal warden or other person who has reason to believe that any dog is killing livestock, or committing any of the depredations mentioned in this section, shall apply to a magistrate of the county, city or town wherein such dog may be, who shall issue a warrant requiring the owner or custodian, if known, to appear before a general district court at a time and place named in the warrant, at which time evidence shall be heard. If it shall appear that the dog is a livestock killer, or has committed any of the depredations mentioned in this section, the district court shall order that the dog be: 
(1)  Killed immediately by the animal warden or other officer designated by the court; or 
(2)  Removed to another state that does not border on the commonwealth and prohibited from returning to the commonwealth. Any dog order removed from the commonwealth which is later found in the commonwealth shall be ordered by a court to be killed immediately. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796-116. 
Sec. 5-6. - Compensation for livestock and poultry killed by dogs. 
(a)  Any person who has any livestock or poultry killed by any dog not his own shall be entitled to receive as compensation the fair market value of such livestock or poultry not to exceed four hundred dollars ($400.00) per animal or ten dollars ($10.00) per fowl, provided that the: 
(1)  The claimant has furnished evidence within sixty (60) days of discovery of the quantity and value of the dead or injured livestock and the reasons the claimant believes that death or injury was caused by a dog; 
(2)  Animal warden or other officer shall have been notified of the incident within seventy-two (72) hours of its discovery; and 
(3)  Claimant first has exhausted his legal remedies against the owner, if known, of the dog doing the damage for which compensation under this section is sought. Exhaustion shall mean a judgment against the owner of the dog upon which an execution has been returned unsatisfied. 
(b)  The council may by ordinance waive the requirements of subsections (a)(1) or (a)(2), or both, provided that the ordinance adopted requires that the animal warden has conducted an investigation and that his investigation supports the claim. Upon payment under this section, the council shall be subrogated to the extent of compensation paid to the right of action to the owner of the livestock or poultry against the owner of the dog and may enforce the same in an appropriate action at law. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001; Ord. No. 85, 5-12-2004) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.118. 
Sec. 5-7. - Unlawful acts. 
    The following shall be deemed unlawful acts and constitute class 4 misdemeanors: 
(1)  Diseased dogs. For the owner of any dog with a contagious or infectious disease to permit such dog to stray from his premised is such disease is known to the owner. 
(1)  Female dog in season. For the owner of any female dog to permit such dog to stray from his premises while such dog is known to such owner to be in season. 
(3)  Removing collar and tag. For any person except the owner or custodian to remove a legally acquired license tag from a dog without the permission of the owner or custodian. 
(4)  Concealing a dog. For any person to conceal or harbor any dog for which the license tax has not been paid or to conceal a mad dog to keep the same from being killed. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-8. - Dogs deemed personal property; rights relating thereto. 
(a)  All dogs shall be deemed personal property and may be the subject of larceny and malicious or unlawful trespass. Owners, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.66, may maintain any action for the killing of any such animals, or injury thereto, or unlawful detention or use thereof as in the case of other personal property. The owner of any dog which is injured or killed contrary to the provisions of this chapter by any person shall be entitled to recover the value thereof or the damage done thereto in an appropriate action at law from such person. 
(b)  An animal warden or other officer finding a stolen dog, or a dog held or detained contrary to law, shall have authority to seize and hold such animal pending action before a general district court or other court. If no such action is instituted within seven (7) days, the animal warden or other officer shall deliver the dog to its owner. 
(c)  The presence of a dog on the premises of a person other than its legal owner shall raise no presumption of theft against the owner, and the animal warden may take such animal in charge and notify its legal owner to remove it. The legal owner of the animal shall pay a reasonable charge as the town council by ordinance shall establish for the keep of such animal while in the possession of the animal warden. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-9. - Pound; confinement and disposition of stray animals. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning; 
    Animal shall not include agricultural animals. 
    Humane society, when referring to an organization without the commonwealth, means any nonprofit organization organized for the purposes of preventing cruelty to animals and promoting humane care and treatment or adoption of animals. 
    Rightful owner means a person with a right of property in the animal. 
(b)  Keeping of confined animals. 
(1)  An animal confined pursuant to this section shall be kept for period of not less than five (5) days, such period to commence on the day immediately following the day the animal is initially confined in the facility, unless sooner claimed by the rightful owner thereof. 
(2)  The operator or custodian of the pound shall make a reasonable effort to ascertain whether the animal has a collar, tag, license, tattoo or other from of identification. If such identification is found on the animal, the animal shall be held for an additional five (5) days unless sooner claimed by the rightful owner. If the rightful owner of the animal can be readily identified, the operator or custodian of the pound shall make a reasonable effort to notify the owner of the animals' confinement within the next forty-eight (48) hours following its confinement. 
(3)  If any animal confined pursuant to this section is claimed by its rightful owner, such owner shall be charged with the actual expenses incurred in keeping the animal impounded, including veterinary fees. 
(c)  Disposition. If an animal confined pursuant to this section has not been claimed upon expiration of the appropriate holding period as provided by subsection (c) of this section, it shall be deemed abandoned and become the property of the pound or shelter. If such abandoned animal did not when delivered to the pound bear a collar, tag, license, tattoo or other form of identification, it may be humanely destroyed or disposed of by: 
(1)  Sale or gift to a federal agency, state-supported institution, agency of the commonwealth, agency of another state, or a licensed federal dealer having its principal place of business located within the commonwealth, provided that such agency, institution or dealer agrees to confine the animal for an additional period of not less than five (5) days; 
(2)  Delivery to any humane society or animal shelter within the commonwealth. 
(3)  Delivery by any person who is a resident of the town/county and who will pay the required license fee, if any, on such animal; 
(4)  Adoption by a resident of an adjacent political subdivision of the commonwealth; or 
(5)  Delivery, for the purposes of adoption or euthanasia only, to a humane society or an animal shelter located in and lawfully operating under the laws of another state, provided that such humane society or animal shelter; 
a.  Maintains records which would comply with Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.105; 
b.  Requires that adopted dogs and cats be sterilized; and 
c.  Has been approved by the state veterinarian or his designee as a facility which maintains such records, requires adopted dogs and cats to be sterilized, and provides adequate care and euthanasia. 
If such abandoned animal when delivered to the pound bore a collar, tag, license, tattoo or other form of identification, it may be humanely destroyed or disposed of by the methods described in subsections (c)(2), (c)(3) or (c)(4) of this section. No pound or shelter shall deliver more than two (2) animals or a family of animals during any thirty-day period to any one person under subsection (c)(3) or (c)(4) of this section. 
(d)  Destruction of ill animals. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the immediate destruction of a critically injured, critically ill, or unweaned animal for humane purposes. Any animal destroyed pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be euthanized by one (1) of the methods prescribed or approved by the state veterinarian. 
(e)  Disposal by owner. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the immediate destruction or disposal by the methods listed in subsections (d)(2)-(5) of an animal that has been delivered voluntarily or released to a pound, animal shelter, animal warden or humane society by the animal's rightful owner after the rightful owner has, in writing, surrendered all property rights in such animal and has read and signed a statement certifying that no other person has a right of property in the animal and acknowledging that the animal may be immediately euthanized or disposed of by the methods listed in subsections (d)(2)-(5). 
(f)  Euthanizing feral dogs, cats. Nothing in this section shall prohibit any feral dog or feral cat not bearing a collar, tag, tattoo or other form of identification which, based on the written certification of a disinterested person, exhibits behavior that poses a risk of physical injury to any person confining the animal, from being euthanized after being kept for a period of not less than three (3) days, at least one (1) of which shall be a full business day, such period to commence on the day the animal is initially confined in the facility, unless sooner claimed by the rightful owner. The certification of the disinterested person shall be kept with the animal as required by Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.105. For purposes of this subsection, a disinterested person shall not include a person releasing or reporting the animal to the facility. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 122, adopted Feb. 11, 2009, repealed § 5-10 which pertained to license required for cats and derived from Ord. No. 74, 6-11-2003. 
Secs. 5-11-5-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VICIOUS AND DANGEROUS DOGS 

Sec. 5-39. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dangerous dog means a canine or canine crossbreed that has bitten, attacked or inflicted injury on a person or companion animal, other than a dog, or killed a companion animal. 
    Vicious dog means a canine or canine crossbreed that has: 
(1)  Killed a person: 
(2)  Inflicted serious injury to a person, including multiple bites, serious disfigurement, serious impairment of health, or serious impairment of a bodily function; or 
(3)  Continued to exhibit the behavior that resulted in a previous finding by a court that it is a dangerous dog, provided that its owner has been given notice of that finding. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-40. - Owner to appear in court. 
    Any animal warden who has reason to believe that a canine or canine crossbreed within his jurisdiction is a dangerous dog or vicious dog shall apply to a magistrate of the jurisdiction for the issuance of a summons requiring the owner or custodian, if known, to appear before a general district court at a specified time. The summons shall advise the owner of the nature of the proceeding and the matters at issue. The animal warden or owner shall confine the animal until such time as evidence shall be heard and a verdict rendered. The court, through its contempt powers, may compel the owner, custodian or harborer of the animal to produce the animal. If after hearing the evidence the court finds that the animal is a dangerous dog, the court shall order the animal's owner to comply with the provisions of this article. If, after hearing the evidence, the court finds that the animal is a vicious dog, the court shall order the animal euthanized in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.119. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-41. - Determination. 
    No canine or canine crossbreed shall be found to be a dangerous dog or vicious dog solely because it is a particular breed, nor shall the local governing body prohibit the ownership of a particular breed of canine or canine crossbreed. No animal shall be found to be a dangerous dog or vicious dog if the threat, injury or damage was sustained by a person who was: 
(1)  Committing, at the time, a crime upon the premises occupied by the animal's owner or custodian; 
(2)  Committing, at the time, a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the animal's owner or custodian; or 
(3)  Provoking, tormenting or physically abusing the animal, or can be shown to have repeatedly provoked, tormented, abused or assaulted the animal at other times. 
    No police dog which was engaged in the performance of its duties as such at the time of the acts complained of shall be found to be a dangerous dog or a vicious dog. No animal which, at the time of the acts complained of, was responding to pain or injury, or was protecting itself, its kennel, its offspring, or its owner or owner's property, shall be found to be a dangerous dog or a vicious dog. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-42. - Registration certificate. 
(a)  Required. The owner of any animal found to be a dangerous dog shall, within ten (10) days of such finding, obtain a dangerous dog registration certificate from the animal warden for a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) in addition to other fees that may be authorized by law. The animal warden shall also provide the owner with a uniformly designed tag which identifies the animal as a dangerous dog. The owner shall affix the tag to the animal's collar and ensure that the animal wears the collar and tag at all times. All certificates obtained pursuant to this section shall be renewed annually for the same fee and in the same manner as the initial certificate was obtained. 
(b)  Issuance. 
(1)  All certificates or renewals required to be obtained under this section shall only be issued to persons eighteen (18) years of age or older who present satisfactory evidence: 
a.  Of the animal's current rabies vaccination, if applicable; and 
b.  That the animal is and will be confined in a proper enclosure or is and will be confined inside the owner's residence or is and will be muzzled and confined in the owner's fenced-in yard until the proper enclosure is constructed. 
(2)  In addition, owners who apply for certificates or renewals under this section shall not be issued a certificate or renewal thereof unless they present satisfactory evidence that: 
a.  Their residence is and will continue to be posted with clearly visible signs warning both minors and adults of the presence of a dangerous dog on the property; and 
b.  The animal has been permanently identified by means of a tattoo on the inside thigh or by electronic implantation. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-43. - Confinement; leash. 
(a)  While on the property of its owner, an animal found to be a dangerous dog shall be confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked structure of sufficient height and design to prevent its escape or direct contact with or entry by minors, adults, or other animals. The structure shall be designed to provide the animal with shelter from the elements of nature. 
(b)  When off its owner's property, an animal found to be a dangerous dog shall be kept on a leash and muzzled in such a manner as not to cause injury to the animal or interfere with the animal's vision or respiration, but so as to prevent it from biting a person or another animal. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-44. - Ownership by minors. 
    If the owner of an animal found to be a dangerous dog is a minor, the custodial parent or legal guardian shall be responsible for complying with all requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-45. - Notification of change in status. 
    After an animal has been found to be a dangerous dog, the animal's owner shall immediately, upon learning of same, notify the animal warden if the animal: 
(1)  If loose or unconfined: 
(2)  Bites a person or attacks another animal; 
(3)  Is sold, given away, or dies; or 
(4)  Has been moved to a different address. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-46. - Disposition of fees. 
    All fees collected pursuant to this article, less the costs incurred by the animal warden in producing and distributing the certificates and tags required by this article, shall be paid into a special dedicated fund in the town treasury for the purpose of paying the expenses of any training course required under Code of Virginia, § 3.1.796.105. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-47. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    The owner of any animal that has been found to be a dangerous or vicious dog who willfully fails to comply with the requirements of this article shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Secs. 5-48-5-67. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RABIES 

Sec. 5-68. - Declaration of a quarantine. 
    When in the judgment of the county health director an emergency is deemed to exist in the town or any section of the town due to widespread rabies epizootic, the health director may declare a quarantine in the town or such section of the town as may be affected and restrict all dogs and cats to the owners' premises and/or to the immediate custody of a responsible person for the duration of such emergency as is set forth. During such period, the animal may be leashed under restraint of the owner in such a manner that persons or animals will not be subject to the danger of being bitten by a rabid animal. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-69. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by all public officers of the town, police chief and his officers and the town animal warden. 
Sec. 5-70. - Penalties. 
    It shall be unlawful and constitute a class 4 misdemeanor for any person to violate any of the provisions of this article or present either a certificate of vaccination for a dog other than that for which it was issued or an authorized certificate of vaccination. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-71. - Inoculation of dogs and cats required. 
    The owner or custodian of all dogs and cats four (4) months of age and older shall have them currently vaccinated for rabies by a licensed veterinarian or licensed veterinary technician who is under the immediate and direct supervision of a licensed veterinarian on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001; Ord. No. 75, 7-9-2003) 
Secs. 5-72-5-91. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEAD ANIMALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-92. - Burial or cremation of dead animals and fowl. 
(a)  When the owner of any animal or grown fowl that has dies knows of such death, such owner shall forthwith have its body buried or cremated. If he fails to do so, any judge of a general district court, after notice to the owner if he can be ascertained, shall cause any such dead animal or fowl to be buried or cremated by an officer or other person designated for the purpose. 
(b)  Such officer or other person shall be entitled to recover from the owner of every such animal so cremated or buried the actual cost of the cremation or burial, not to exceed seventy-five dollars ($75.00), and from the owner of every such fowl so cremated or buried the actual cost of the cremation or burial, not to exceed five dollars ($5.00), to be recovered in the same manner as officers' fees are recovered, free from all exemptions in favor of such owner. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-93. - Commercial, food use of animal. 
    Nothing in this division shall be deemed to require the burial or cremation of the whole or portions of any animal or fowl that is to be used for food or in any commercial manner. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Secs. 5-94-5-123. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ANIMALS DYING FROM DISEASE 

Sec. 5-124. - Burial or cremation of animals and fowl dying of disease. 
    The owner of any animal or grown fowl that has died of a disease, knowing of such death, shall forthwith bury or cause to be buried, cremate or cause to be cremated, or deliver immediately to some rendering company approved by health director or county agent the body of such animal or grown fowl. If he fails to do so, any magistrate, after notice to the owner if he can be ascertained, shall cause any such dead animal or fowl to be cremated or buried by a constable or other person designated for the purpose. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-125. - Fees. 
    The constable or other person designated for the purpose of cremating or burying an animal or fowl that has died of a disease shall be entitled to recover from the owner of every such animal so cremated or buried the actual cost of the cremation or burial, not to exceed seventy-five dollars ($75.00), and from the owner of every such fowl so cremated or buried the actual cost of the cremation or burial, not to exceed five dollars ($5.00), to be recovered in the same manner as officers' fees are recovered, free from all exemptions in favor of such owner. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-126. - Diseased animals at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any animal or grown fowl suffering from a disease that is likely to result in the death of the animal or grown fowl to knowingly permit the same to run at large or go upon the public highways or premises of another, or to fail to confine such animal or grown fowl so that it will not likely endanger the health of animals or fowl of others. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-127. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this division shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Secs. 5-128-5-147. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GENERAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 5-148. - Annual permit. 
    An annual permit, obtained from the town manager's office is required for the keeping of animals or fowl other than dogs and cats. A fee may be charged to allow for the cost incurred. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-149. - Animals or fowl prohibited within occupied building or residence, nor near well, spring, stream, creek or brook. 
    In the preservation of public safety and human health, no animal or fowl, other than dogs and cats may be kept within one hundred (100) feet of an occupied building or residence. Nor shall they be permitted within fifty (50) feet of a well, spring, stream, creek or brook. Reference Code of Virginia 1995 as amended § 3.1-796.94:1. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-150. - Emergency veterinary treatment. 
    The owner shall bear the expense or cost of emergency veterinary treatment when an animal is in custody of the animal warden, providing there is no negligence on the warden's part. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Sec. 5-151. - Animal excreta or waste. 
(a)  The owner of an animal shall be responsible for the removal of any waste or feces deposited by such owner's animal on public and private property. 
(b)  Waste or excreta deposited by an animal on public property or on the private property of any person other than such animal's owner shall be collected and removed immediately by such animal's owner. Animal waste or excreta deposited on any other property shall be collected and removed daily. 
(c)  Collection and removal of animal waste or excreta shall be in a container of such a type that, when closed, is ratproof and flyproof. Such container shall be kept closed after each collection. At least once a week, each such animal owner shall cause all waste or excreta so collected to be disposed of in such a manner as not to permit fly breeding. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001) 
Secs. 5-152-5-171. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CRUELTY TO ANIMALS 

Sec. 5-172. - Cruelty to animals; penalty. 
(a)  Any person who (i) overrides, overdrives, overloads, tortures, ill-treats, abandons, willfully inflicts inhumane injury or pain not connected with bona fide scientific or medical experimentation, or cruelly or unnecessarily beats, maims, mutilates, or kills any animal, whether belonging to himself or another; or (ii) deprives any animal of necessary food, drink, shelter or emergency veterinary treatment; or (iii) willfully sets on foot, instigates, engages in, or in any way furthers any act of cruelty to any animal; or (iv) carries or causes to be carried in or upon any vehicle, vessel or otherwise any animal in a cruel, brutal, or inhumane manner, so as to produce torture or unnecessary suffering; or (v) causes any of the above things, or being the owner of such animal permits such acts to be done by another, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person who (i) tortures, willfully inflicts inhumane injury or pain not connected with bonafide scientific or medical experimentation, or cruelly and unnecessarily beats, maims, mutilates or kills any animal whether belonging to himself or another; or (ii) instigates, engages in, or in any way furthers any act of cruelty to any animal set forth in clause (i) of this subsection; or (iii) causes any of the actions described in subdivisions (i) and (ii) of this subsection, or being the owner of such animal permits such acts to be done by another; and has been within five (5) years convicted of a violation of this subsection or subsection (a), shall be guilty of a class 6 felony if the current violation or any previous violation of this subsection or subsection (a) resulted in the death of an animal or the euthanasia of an animal based on the recommendation of a licensed veterinarian upon determination that such euthanasia was necessary due to the condition of this animal, and such condition was a direct result of a violation of this subsection or subsection (a). 
(c)  Any person who abandons any dog, cat or other domesticated animal in any public place including the right-of-way of any public highway, road or street or on the property of another shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(d)  This section shall not prohibit authorized wildlife management activities or hunting, fishing or trapping as regulated under other titles of the Code of Virginia, including, but not limited to Title 29.1, or to farming activities as provided under this title or regulations promulgated thereto. 
(e)  In addition to the penalties provided in subsection (a), the court may, in its discretion, require any person convicted of a violation of subsection (a) to attend an anger management or other appropriate treatment program or obtain psychiatric or psychological counseling. The court may impose the costs of such a program or counseling upon the person convicted. 
(f)  It is unlawful for any person to kill a domestic dog or cat for the purpose of obtaining the hide, fur or pelt of the dog or cat. A violation of this subsection shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. A second or subsequent violation of this subsection shall constitute a class 6 misdemeanor. Reference Code of Virginia as amended § 3.1-796.122. 
(Ord. No. 61, 12-12-2001)

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Building code adopted. 
(a)  The provisions of the International Building Code (IBC), latest edition adopted by the state, are hereby adopted. This publication, compiled and published by the International Code Council, Inc. (ICC) constitutes, in part, the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code as described in the Code of Virginia 1950, as amended, provided that in the event any provision of the Code of Virginia shall be in conflict with or contrary to the above mentioned International Building Code or supplement, the law of the state shall control absolutely and without question. 
(b)  One (1) copy of the above mentioned International Building Code publication shall be maintained by the town manager and the town building official, respectively, and shall be available to the public for use at their respective offices. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003) 
Charter reference- Adoption of building code, § 24. 
Sec. 6-2. - Building official. 
(a)  The town building official shall be appointed by the town manager, subject to the approval of town council. The town manager shall provide him with appropriate supervision and working facilities, subject to the approval of town council. The position classifications plan of the town shall specifically set forth the qualifications and the salary of the town building official. His duties and powers shall be as follows: 
(1)  To enforce provisions from the International Building Code, as well as the specific electrical, mechanical and plumbing codes contained in this chapter. 
(2)  To make all required inspections to ensure the enforcement of subsection (1) above. 
(3)  To receive all applications and issue all permits for the erection or alteration of buildings or structures. 
(4)  To issue all orders or notices necessary to remove any illegal or unsafe conditions in any building or structure whether under construction or previously constructed. 
(5)  To keep official records of the activities of his office, such records to be open for public inspection at appropriate times. 
(6)  To perform any and all additional responsibilities as may be assigned to him by the town manager or town council. 
(b)  The town building official shall not have the power to change any rules or regulations prescribed under any section of this Code without the express consent of the town council. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 6-3. - Moving of buildings. 
(a)  No building or part of any building shall be moved through or across any sidewalk, street, alley or highway within the corporate limits of the town without first obtaining a permit from the town manager; provided, that nothing herein set forth shall be construed to require a permit for the moving of any structure the size and character of which does impede, disrupt or interfere with the normal flow of traffic and the nature of which does not pose a hazard to the public, public property or private property along the route of such moving. 
(b)  Any person desiring to move a building shall first file with the town manager a written application setting forth the following information: 
(1)  Type and kind of building to be moved. 
(2)  The original cost of the building. 
(3)  The extreme dimension: length, height and width of the building. 
(4)  The present location of the building and the proposed new location by lot, block, subdivision and street numbers. 
(5)  The approximate time such building will be upon the streets, and the contemplated route that will be taken from present to new location. 
(c)  If, in the opinion of the town manager, the moving of any building will cause serious injury to persons or property or serious injury to the streets or other public improvements, or moving of the building will violate any of the requirements of this Code or of the zoning regulations of the town, the permit shall not be issued, and the building shall not be moved over the streets of the town. 
(d)  Any building being moved for which permit was granted shall not be allowed to remain in or on the streets of the town for more than forty-eight (48) hours. 
(e)  The town manager, as a condition precedent to the issuance of such permit, shall require a bond to be executed by the person desiring such permit, with corporate surety to his satisfaction. Such bond shall be made payable to the town and for such amount as he prescribes, but in no event to be less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). It shall indemnify the town against any and all damage caused by the moving of such building to streets, curbs, sidewalks, shade trees, highways and any other property which may be affected by the moving of a building. Such surety bond shall also be conditioned upon and liable for strict compliance with the terms of such permit, as to route to be taken and limit of time in which to effect such removal and to repair or compensate for the repair and to pay the town as liquated damages an amount not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) to be prescribed by the town manager for each and every day's delay in completing such removal or in repairing any damage to property or public improvement or in clearing all public streets, alleys or highways of any debris occasioned thereby. 
(f)  Any persons desiring to move any building shall, at no expense to the town, secure and maintain in force, during the entire time that the building is being moved, all forms of insurance for the protection of the mover, the town, and the general public, against any damage, liability, claim or lawsuit arising from or in connection with the moving of the building. Such person desiring to move any building against any and all claims, liabilities and damages, including the costs of defending the town therefrom, arising from or in connection with moving any building. 
(g)  Prior to the issuance of a permit to move any building, there shall be paid to the town treasurer a fee for such permit in the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(h)  The following provisions for public safety are required: 
(1)  Lights required. Every building which occupies any portion of public property after sundown shall have sufficient lights continuously burning between sunset and sunrise for the protection of the public. 
(2)  Number and location of lights. There shall be a minimum of five (5) red lights placed on each street around the building; such red lights shall be attached to the building in such a fashion as to indicate extreme width, height and size. 
(3)  Flares required. There shall be placed in addition to the red lights on the building, flares at regular intervals for a distance of two hundred (200) feet up the street on each side of the building. 
(4)  Flagmen required. When more than fifty (50) percent of the street, measured between curbs, is occupied at night by the building, or when, in the opinion of the town manager, flagmen are necessary to divert or caution traffic, the owner or person moving such building shall employ at their expense two (2) flagmen, one (1) at each street intersection beyond the building; such flagmen shall remain at these intersections diverting or cautioning traffic from sunset to sunrise. Red lights shall be employed in flagging traffic at night. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003) 
Cross reference- Moving vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15. 
Sec. 6-4. - Board of appeals. 
    The town council shall have full and exclusive authority to appoint members of any board of appeals; otherwise, a board of appeals shall function exactly as described in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 6-5. - Schedule of fees-Building permits. 
    The following fees for building permits are hereby levied in accordance with and by the authority of the Code of Virginia 1950, as amended. No permit shall be issued until the fees prescribed herein are paid, nor shall any amendment to a permit be granted until the additional fee, if any, has been paid. Any person who fails to obtain a permit before commencing work shall be punishable under section 6-8 of this chapter. Any fees required by this schedule shall be paid at the time application is made. The fees shall be affixed at the following rates: 
(1)  Residential: New construction and structural renovations-One- and two-family dwellings: 
Single-family dwellings (total footprint) ..... $75.00 base fee + $0.20 /sq. ft. 
Renovations (total renovated space) 
Structural only ..... $75.00 base fee + $0.20/sq. ft. 
Non-structural renovations that do not involve adding, removing, or changing any structural member of the building: 
Base fee and trade permits: 
Mobile/modular homes ..... $75.00 + $0.15/sq. ft. 
Separate plumbing, electric and HVAC ..... $75.00 each 
Garages and additions ..... $50.00 base fee + $0.15/sq. ft. 
Porches, sheds and decks ..... .15/sq. ft. ($50.00 minimum) 
Demolition: 
Residential accessory structure ..... $50.00 
Residential homes ..... $75.00 
Commercial or industrial buildings ..... $125.00 
Swimming pools: 
In-ground pools ..... $125.00 
Above ground pools ..... $75.00 
(2)  Commercial: New Construction and structural renovations: $150.00 Base Fee + $0.25/sq. ft. 
Non-structural renovations that do not involve adding, removing, or changing any structural member of the building: 
Base fee and trade permits: 
Separate plumbing, electric and HVAC etc. ..... $150.00 each 
Commercial accessory structure ..... $150.00 + $0.25 /sq. ft. 
(3)  Other inspections: 
Electric upgrade or change service ..... $75.00 
Re-inspection fee ..... $30.00-after 2nd failure 
Signs 
a. Non-illuminated flush mounted wall signs ..... $45.00 
b. All other signs ..... $75.00 
Moving building or structure ..... $150.00 
Plan review ..... $200.00 
Certificate of occupancy for existing buildings - amending or transfer of a permit ..... $50.00 
The commonwealth imposes a two (2) percent levy which will be assessed to all building permit fees. 
Request for refund, eighty (80) percent of permit cost. The refund must be requested in writing within six (6) months of the application date or within six (6) months of the issue date, where no inspections have been performed. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003; Ord. No. 142, 7-13-2011; Ord. No. 146, 9-14-2011) 
Sec. 6-6. - Same-Inspections of both mechanical and general construction work. 
    The fees for inspections of both mechanical and general construction work are hereby levied in accordance with the Code of Virginia 1950, as amended, and section 6-5 of this chapter. No such work shall be certified by the town building official until such fees are paid. Any person who fails to obtain a required inspection from the town building official shall be deemed in violation of this chapter, and shall be punishable under section 6-8. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003) 
Sec. 6-7. - Relocation and installation of mobile homes. 
    All mobile homes relocated or installed in the town after December 6, 1975, must be provided with mounting and anchorage for stabilization. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003) 
Sec. 6-8. - Penalty for violation of this article. 
    Pursuant to the Code of Virginia 1950, as amended, any person who violates this article shall be deemed to be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. Any person convicted of a second offense committed within less than five (5) years after a first offense under this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). Any person convicted of a second offense committed within a period of five (5) to ten (10) years of a first offense under this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). Any person convicted of a third or subsequent offense involving the same property committed within ten (10) years of an offense under this chapter after having been at least twice previously convicted shall be punished by confinement in jail for not more than ten (10) days and a fine of not less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) nor more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), either or both. No portion of the fine imposed for such third or subsequent offense committed within ten (10) years of an offense under this chapter shall be suspended. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003) 
Sec. 6-9. - Article supplemental to International Building Codes. 
    The provisions of this article shall be construed to be supplemental and in additional to the requirements contained in the International Building Codes; provided, that any part of this article in conflict with any provision in such code, the International Building Code shall take precedence. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003) 
Sec. 6-10. - Building maintenance code. 
(a)  Official action. The Town of Farmville is hereby designated to act as the enforcing agency for the enforcement of "The Building Maintenance Code" of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, duly adopted by the Virginia Board of Housing and Community Development under the authority of the Code of Virginia 1950, as amended. Enforcement shall be according to the terms of this section. 
(b)  Enforcement. The enforcement procedures of "The Building Maintenance Code" shall be instituted by the code official when a written complaint is filed with the code official. 
(c)  Appeals. The town board of appeals is hereby designated as the appeals board to hear appeals arising from the application of the provisions of "The Building Maintenance Code". 
(d)  Administrative practices. The code official shall establish such procedures or requirements as may be necessary for administration and enforcement of this section. The procedures are to be approved by town council. 
(Ord. No. 79, 12-10-2003) 
Secs. 6-11-6-20. - Reserved.
