(b)  The presence of any metering device found to have been altered, tampered with, or bypassed in a manner that would cause such metering device to inaccurately measure and register the degree, amount or quantity of such service supplied or which would cause such service to be diverted from the recording apparatus of the meter shall be prima facie evidence of intent to violate and of the violation of this section by the person to whose benefit it is that such service be unmetered, unregistered or diverted. 
(Code 1973, § 18-34) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-163. 
Sec. 18-43. - Trespassing-Generally. 
(a)  If any person, not an officer, without the consent of the owner, proprietor or custodian or without authority of the law shall go upon the lands or premises of another where a "No Trespassing" sign has been placed thereon or if any person shall go upon the premises of another after having been forbidden to do so by the owner, proprietor or custodian or other person lawfully in charge or possession of such land or premises or if any person in the nighttime shall go upon the premises on which there is located a residence or other building without such consent or authority or unless for some lawful purpose, he shall be deemed guilty of trespass. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, not an officer, to enter the dwelling of another without the consent of the owner or other person having a legal right to give such consent or to enter a storehouse or any other building of another without such consent expressed or implied. 
(Code 1973, § 18-46) 
Cross reference- Trespassing at night on cemetery property, § 8-18. 
Sec. 18-44. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 166, adopted June 12, 2013 , repealed § 18-44, which pertained to railroad trains generally. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 18-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 166, adopted June 12, 2013 , repealed § 18-45, which pertained to trespassers forbidden to jump on or off railroad cars or trains. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 18-46. - Weapons-Carrying concealed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry hid from common observation any pistol, dirk, bowie knife, switchblade knife, razor or any weapon of like kind, subject to the exceptions provided by Code of Virginia, § 18.2-308. 
(Code 1973, § 18-47) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-308. 
Sec. 18-47. - Same-Discharge of firearms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any cannon, gun, pistol, revolver or firearm of any description, without necessity, unless the person doing the same is an officer acting within the duties of his office. Provided, that no hunting, and discharging of firearms shall be closer than one hundred (100) yards of any dwelling, building, playgrounds or improved area. Also a permit shall be obtained from the chief of police to discharge all firearms within the corporate limits. 
(Code 1973, § 18-48; Ord. No. 166, 6-12-2013 ; Ord. No. 176 , 7-13-2016) 
Cross reference- Discharge of firearms at airport, § 4-4; discharge of firearms in cemetery, § 8-19. 
Sec. 18-48. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 152 , adopted April 2012, repealed § 18-48, which pertained to weapons-permits for purchase and sale and derived from § 18-49 of the 1973 Code. 
Sec. 18-49. - Weapons-Sale to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter, give, furnish or cause to be sold, bartered, given or furnished to any minor under eighteen (18) years of age a pistol, dirk or bowie knife, having good reason to believe him to be a minor under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Code 1973, § 18-50) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-309. 
Sec. 18-50. - Urination or defecation in public. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or defecate in or on any sidewalk, street, or in any place visible or open to the public where other persons are present, unless such urination or defecation be in a bathroom, restroom, or other facility specifically designed for such purpose. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 80, 12-10-2003) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 66, adopted July 10, 2002, rescinded § 18-50, which pertained to yard sales; permit required and derived from Code 1973, § 18-51. 
Chapter 19 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15; noise control, Ch. 16; nuisances, Ch. 17; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 23; zoning, Ch. 29; licensing of peddlers, § 14-63; licenses for soliciting subscriptions and contributions, § 14-71; solicitations for contributions without permit, § 18-40. 
State Law reference- Local regulation of door-to-door vendors, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-37.3:1, 15.1-37.3:2; protection of the property and inhabitants of the town, preservation of peace and good order, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-137; solicitation of contributions, Code of Virginia, § 57-48 et seq.; local ordinances relating to charitable solicitations, Code of Virginia, § 57-63; local licensing of peddlers, itinerant merchants and direct sellers, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3717 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Street drumming. 
    No person shall obstruct or interfere in any way with the passage of persons along the streets or sidewalks in the town for the purpose of inducing them to purchase any article or thing, or importune passersby to make any such purchase, or enter any such establishment, or, in any disorderly manner, solicit trade, customers or patronage along the streets or sidewalks in the town. 
(Code 1973, § 19-1) 
Sec. 19-2. - Tradesmen certification standards. 
(a)  Official action. The Town of Farmville building department is hereby designated to act as the enforcing agency for the enforcement of the Virginia Tradesmen Certification Standards, duly adopted by the Virginia Board of Housing and Community Development under authority of Code of Virginia §§ 15.1-11.4 and 36-99. Enforcement shall be according, to the terms of this section. 
(b)  Enforcement. The enforcement of the tradesmen certification standards shall be instituted by the town building department in accordance with the provisions of the Virginia Tradesmen Certification Standards. 
(c)  Fees. Every person making application for examination pursuant to this section shall pay a fee of forty-five dollars ($45.00). Application fees paid pursuant to this section shall not be refunded to either successful or unsuccessful applicants. 
(d)  Appeals. The town building board of appeals is hereby designated as the appeals board to hear appeals arising from the application or interpretation of the tradesmen certification standards. 
(e)  Administrative practices. The town building department shall establish such procedures or requirements as may be necessary for administration and enforcement of this section. The procedures are to be approved by the town council. 
(f)  Violation of section. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, on or after the effective date of this section, to violate any provision. Any such violation shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person, firm or corporation convicted of a violation shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(g)  Effective date. This section shall become effective 12:01 a.m. following the date of its adoption. 
(h)  Exemption. Upon initial adoption of the tradesmen certification standards, any person who meets the requirements of section 2.1A, is eligible to file for exemption from any further local certification requirement under this program. 
(i)  Temporary certification. Temporary certification shall be made available upon initial adoption of the tradesmen certification standards and shall be administered in accordance with section 2.2, temporary certification, of these standards. 
(Ord. No. 23, §§ 1-9, 7-14-93) 
Secs. 19-3-19-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLICITORS 

Sec. 19-26. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "solicitor" means a person who goes from door to door visiting multifamily or single-family dwellings for the following purposes: 
(1)  To sell any goods, wares or merchandise or accept subscriptions or orders therefor. 
(2)  To accept or request donations for any charitable purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 19-2) 
Sec. 19-27. - Registration required. 
    Each person, before entering into or upon a residential premises within the town for the purpose of soliciting, shall register with the chief of police and furnish him with the following information: 
(1)  The name, local and permanent addresses, age, race, weight, height, color of hair and eyes and any other distinguishing physical characteristics of the applicant. 
(2)  The nature or purpose for which solicitations will be made and the nature of the goods, wares and merchandise offered for sale. 
(3)  The name and address of the employer or organization represented. 
(4)  A statement as to whether the applicant has been convicted of any felony or misdemeanor, and if so, the nature of the offense, when and where convicted and the penalty or punishment assessed therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 19-3) 
Sec. 19-28. - Issuance of permit; term; display. 
    Upon furnishing the information required under section 19-27, the applicant shall be issued a permit, unless the information furnished in compliance with this article shows that the applicant has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude. A permit issued under this article shall be good for one (1) year from the date of issuance, unless earlier revoked as provided in this article. Every solicitor shall carry his permit with him at all times while engaged in soliciting, and shall display the same to any person who shall demand to see the same while he is so engaged. 
(Code 1973, § 19-4) 
Sec. 19-29. - Fingerprinting and photographing of registrants. 
    Before issuing a permit pursuant to this article, the chief of police shall take a photograph and a complete set of fingerprints of every individual registering pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1973, § 19-5) 
Sec. 19-30. - Fees. 
    A fee of five dollars ($5.00) to cover the costs of investigation of the applicant and processing of the application for a permit under this article shall be paid to the chief of police when the application is filed, and shall not be returnable under any circumstances. 
(Code 1973, § 19-6) 
Sec. 19-31. - Revocation of permits. 
    The chief of police or his designated agent shall revoke any permit issued under this article if he finds that the permittee has given false information or has knowingly withheld information in obtaining the same or upon violation of any provision of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 19-7) 
Sec. 19-32. - Prohibited acts. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Enter into or upon a residential premises in the town under false pretenses to solicit for any purpose or for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise. 
(2)  Remain in or on any residential premises after the owner or occupant has requested any such person to leave. 
(3)  Enter upon any residential premises for soliciting, when the owner or occupant has displayed a "No Soliciting" sign on such premises. 
(4)  Engage in the practice of soliciting in the town without a permit as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 19-8) 
Sec. 19-33. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any person who visits any residence or apartment at the request or invitation of the owner or occupant thereof. 
(2)  To unpaid members of any civic or charitable organization registered as such with the chief of police if the names of the solicitors have been listed as such members and the organization has provided each person listed with an approved means of identification with the organization represented. 
(3)  Persons soliciting subscriptions to any newspaper for home delivery within the town. 
(4)  Route delivery persons who make deliveries at least once a week to regular customers and whose solicitation is only incidental to their regular deliveries. 
(Code 1973, § 19-9) 
Chapter 20 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Adoption of master plan, § 24. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; buildings, Ch. 6; erosion and sediment control, Ch. 10; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 23; subdivisions, Ch. 24; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 28; zoning, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Notice of planning or zoning matters, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-33.1; planning, subdivision of land and zoning, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-427 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Scope of chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed so as to affect property lying outside the town; except, that this provision shall not affect planning, platting or other activities now permitted by other laws to be effective outside the town. 
(Code 1973, § 20-1) 
Secs. 20-2-20-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 20-26. - Created. 
    A town planning commission is hereby created. 
(Code 1973, § 20-2) 
State Law reference- Creation of local planning commissions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-427.1. 
Sec. 20-27. - Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  The planning commission shall have the power to promote public interest in and an understanding of the master plan and to that end may publish and distribute copies of the master plan or of any report and may employ such other means of publicity and education as it may determine necessary. Members of the commission, when duly authorized by the commission, may attend planning conferences or meetings of planning institutes or hearings upon pending planning legislation or visit other communities. The commission may, by resolution spread upon its minutes, pay the reasonable traveling expenses incident to such attendance or visit. 
(b)  The planning commission shall, from time to time, recommend to the council programs for public structures and improvements and for the financing thereof and shall consult and advise with public officials and agencies, public utility companies, civil, educational, professional and other organizations and with citizens with relation to the protecting or carrying out of the master plan. All public officials shall, upon request, furnish to the planning commission within a reasonable time such available information as it may require for its work. The planning commission, its members, officers and employees in the performance of their functions may enter upon any land in the town and make examinations and surveys and place and maintain necessary monuments and markers thereon. In general, the planning commission shall have such powers as may be necessary to enable it to fulfill its functions, promote planning or carry out the purposes of this section. The commission shall make an annual report to the council concerning its activities during the year. 
(Code 1973, § 20-3) 
Sec. 20-28. - Members-Appointment; term; compensation; qualifications. 
(a)  The planning commission shall be composed of not more than fifteen (15), nor less than five (5) members. Members of the planning commission shall reside within the corporate limits of the Town of Farmville and shall be appointed by council. Council shall appoint one (1) member from each town ward and two (2) at-large members. In the event that a vacancy on the planning commission cannot be filled with a qualified candidate from a specific ward, council shall fill that vacancy by appointing a qualified candidate from any of the other wards. In addition to the voting members appointed by council, council may also appoint ex-officio members comprised of staff administration, who shall have no power to vote. The role of ex-officio members shall be to assist and advise the voting members, and ex-officio members shall not be subject to the same residential or other requirements as voting members. All voting members, who shall be known as appointed members, shall be registered voters of the town residing within its corporate limits, and shall be qualified by knowledge and experience to make decisions on questions of community growth and development. At all times, a minimum of one-half of the voting members so appointed shall be owners of real property located within the corporate limits of the Town of Farmville. 
(b)  All voting members of the commission shall serve with compensation as set by council. The appointed members shall hold no other municipal office or position, except that they may serve on the board of zoning appeals. The appointed members shall serve a term of four (4) years. Ex-officio members shall be appointed by council at its first regular meeting in July. 
(Code 1973, § 20-4; Ord. No. 89, 12-8-2004; Ord. No. 125, 12-9-2009; Ord. No. 175 , 6-8-2016; Ord. No. 177 , 9-14-2016; Ord. No. 183 , 5-10-2017) 
State Law reference- Qualifications, appointment, removal, terms, compensation, etc., of members of local planning commissions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437. 
Sec. 20-29. - Same-Removal; notice; hearing. 
    Any member may be removed from the planning commission by the council for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office; but such removal shall not be had unless and until a complaint, in writing, is filed in the town clerk's office. Such complaint shall state with reasonable accuracy and detail the grounds or reasons for removal of the member of whom complaint is made and shall be signed by the mayor after proper order by the town council entered on the minutes of the minute book. A notice of the time and place of hearing, together with a copy of the complaint, shall be served upon the member. No such hearing shall be had until and unless such notice has been served upon the member at least thirty (30) days prior to date of hearing. The mayor shall fill all vacancies. 
(Code 1973, § 20-5) 
Sec. 20-30. - Election of chairman; meetings generally. 
    The planning commission shall elect one (1) of its members as chairman and one (1) as vice-chairman; they shall hold office as such for one (1) year with eligibility for re-election. The commission shall hold regular meetings as required by law. It shall adopt rules and regulations for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be public. 
(Code 1973, § 20-6) 
State Law reference- Meetings of planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-439. 
Sec. 20-31. - Appointment of employees; contracts for services not to exceed appropriation. 
    The planning commission may appoint such employees as it may deem necessary for its work. The commission may also contract with city planners, engineers, architects and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditure of the commission, exclusive of gifts to the commission, shall be within the amounts appropriated by the council for that purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 20-7) 
Secs. 20-32-20-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Adoption of master plan, § 24. 
State Law reference- Comprehensive plan to be prepared and adopted, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-446.1. 

Sec. 20-51. - Preparation, adoption; scope and purpose. 
(a)  The planning commission shall prepare and recommend a comprehensive plan for the physical development of the territory within its jurisdiction. The council shall adopt a comprehensive plan for the territory under its jurisdiction. 
(b)  In the preparation of a comprehensive plan the commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of the existing conditions and trends of growth, and of the probable future requirements of its territory and inhabitants. The comprehensive plan shall be made with the purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the territory which will, in accordance with present and probable future needs and resources, best promote the health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare of the inhabitants. 
(c)  The comprehensive plan shall be general in nature, in that it shall designate the general or approximate location, character, and extent of each feature shown on the plan and shall indicate where existing lands or facilities are proposed to be extended, widened, removed, relocated, vacated, narrowed, abandoned or changed in use as the case may be. 
(d)  Such plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts, and descriptive matter, shall show the commission's long-range recommendations for the general development of the territory covered by the plan, including the location of existing or proposed recycling centers. It may include, but need not be limited to: 
(1)  The designation of areas for various types of public and private development and use, such as different kinds of residential, business, industrial, agricultural, conservation, recreation, public service, floodplain and drainage, and other areas. 
(2)  The designation of a system of transportation facilities such as streets, roads, highways, parkways, railways, bridges, viaducts, waterways, airports, ports, terminals and other like facilities. 
(3)  The designation of a system of community service facilities such as parks, forests, schools, playgrounds, public buildings and institutions, hospitals, community centers, waterworks, sewage disposal or waste disposal areas and the like. 
(4)  The designation of historical areas and areas for urban renewal or other treatment. 
(5)  The designation of areas for the implementation of reasonable groundwater protection measures. 
(6)  An official map, a capital improvements program, a subdivision ordinance, and a zoning ordinance and zoning district maps. 
(7)  The designation of areas for the implementation of measures to promote construction of and maintenance of affordable housing. 
(e)  The planning commission is granted power to control, preserve and care for historical landmarks; to control the design and location of statuary and other works of art, which are or may become the property of the town; and to control the removal, relocation and alteration of any such works belonging to the town and to make suggestions concerning the designs of harbors, bridges, viaducts, street fixtures and other public structures and appurtenances. As the work of making the whole comprehensive plan progresses, the planning commission may from time to time adopt and publish a part or parts thereof, any such part to cover one (1) or more major sections or geographic or topographical divisions of the town or one (1) or more of the aforesaid or other functional matters to be included in the plan. The commission may from time to time amend, extend or add to the plan. 
(Code 1973, § 20-8) 
Sec. 20-52. - Purpose. 
    In the preparation of the comprehensive plan, the planning commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and future growth. The comprehensive plan shall be made with the general purposes of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the town and its environs, which will in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, order, convenience and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development. 
(Code 1973, § 20-9) 
Sec. 20-53. - Hearing and notice required before adoption; filing certified copies. 
    Before the adoption of the comprehensive plan or any part, amendment, extension or addition, the planning commission and the council shall hold at least one (1) public hearing thereon, not less than six (6) nor more than twenty-one (21) days' notice of the time and place of which shall be given by publication once a week for two (2) successive weeks in a newspaper published or having general circulation in the town. The adoption of the comprehensive plan or of any part, amendment, extension or addition shall be by resolution of the planning commission, carried by the affirmative votes of not less than a majority of the full membership of the commission. The resolution shall refer expressly to the maps and descriptive and other matter extended by the commission to form the whole or part of the plan, and the action taken shall be recorded on the map and plan, and descriptive matter by the identifying signature of the chairman or secretary of the commission. An attested copy of the plan or any adopted part thereof shall then be certified to the council and to the clerk of the court of the county. 
(Code 1973, § 20-10) 
State Law reference- Notice and hearing on plan, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-448; copy to be certified to governing body, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-449. 
Sec. 20-54. - Approval of construction in area covered by plan. 
(a)  Whenever the planning commission and the council shall have adopted a comprehensive plan for the town or any parts, sections or divisions thereof and the same shall have been filed with the county court clerk, no street, square, park or other public way, ground or open space and no public building or structure shall be constructed or authorized in the town or in the planned section or district thereof until and unless the general location, character and extent thereof shall have been submitted to and approved by the planning commission. 
(b)  No public utility, whether publicly or privately owned which is not subject to zoning control as now provided by law shall be constructed or authorized in the town or in the planned section or district thereof until and unless the reasonable and general location, but not the character and extent thereof, shall have been submitted to and approved by the planning commission. In case of disapproval, the commission shall communicate its reason to the council, which shall have the power to overrule such action by a recorded vote of not less than two-thirds of its entire membership. 
(c)  The failure of the planning commission to act on the proposed change within sixty (60) days after the date of the official submission to it shall be deemed approval of the exchange. The widening, extension, narrowing, enlargement, vacation or change in the use of streets and other public ways, grounds and places within the town, as well as the acquisition by the town or the public of any land within the town for public use or purposes or the sale of any land then held by the town shall be subject to similar approval and in case same is not approved; it may be similarly overruled. The foregoing provision of this section shall not be deemed to apply to the paving, repaving, reconstruction, improvement, drainage or other work of or in or upon any street or other public way or any public building or utility unless it involves a change in the location or extent thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 20-11) 
State Law reference- Legal status of plan, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-456. 
Chapter 21 - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 
  
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Town sergeant, §§ 6, 46 et seq.; appointment of police officers, § 32. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 12; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15; administration of noise control program, § 16-4; report on taxicab business by chief of police, § 26-34. 
State Law reference- Law enforcement officer training standards, Code of Virginia, § 9-179 et seq.; police and public order, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-131 et seq.; Line of Duty Act, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-136.1 et seq.; general municipal law enforcement powers, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-137 et seq.; auxiliary police forces, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-159.2 et seq.; malicious bodily injury to law enforcement officers, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-51.1; impersonation of police officer, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-174, 18.2-175; giving false report to police officer, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-461; criminal procedure, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-1 et seq.; conservators of the peace and special policemen, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-12 et seq.; arrest, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-71 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Control and supervision. 
    The supervision and control of the police department of the town shall be under the town manager. 
(Code 1973, § 22-1) 
Sec. 21-2. - Composition. 
    There shall be a chief of police and such police officers as the council may direct. 
(Code 1973, § 22-2) 
Sec. 21-3. - Duty of chief generally. 
    The chief of police shall examine all violations of this Code, other ordinances and criminal laws of the state and all nuisances within the town and report the same to the town manager and town attorney. 
(Code 1973, § 22-3; Ord. No. 176 , 7-13-2016) 
Sec. 21-4. - Bond of chief of police. 
    The bond of the chief of police shall be two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(Code 1973, § 22-4) 
Charter reference- Bond of town sergeant, § 48. 
Sec. 21-5. - Powers and duties of police force. 
(a)  The officers and privates constituting the police force of the town are hereby invested with all the power and authority which formerly belonged to the office of constable at common law in taking cognizance of, and in enforcing the criminal laws of the commonwealth and the ordinances and regulations of the town. Each police officer shall endeavor to prevent the commission within the town of offenses against the law of the commonwealth and against the ordinances and regulations of the town; shall observe and enforce all such laws, ordinances and regulations; shall detect and arrest offenders against the same; shall preserve the good order of the town; and shall secure the inhabitants thereof from violence and the property therein from injury. 
(b)  Such police officer shall have no power or authority in civil matters, except that a police officer of the town may execute and serve an order of temporary detention pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 37.1-67.1, but a police officer of the town shall in all other cases execute such warrants or summons as may be placed in his hands by any magistrate for the town and shall make due return thereof. 
(c)  Except as otherwise specifically provided in the charter of the town, such police officer shall not receive any fee or other compensation out of the state treasury or the treasury of the town for any service rendered under the provisions of this chapter other than the salary paid him by the town and a fee as a witness in cases arising under the criminal laws of the commonwealth. Except as otherwise specifically provided in the charter of the town, such police officer shall not receive any fee as a witness in any case arising under the ordinances of his town; nor for attendance as a witness before any magistrate in his town. If, however, it shall become necessary or expedient for him to travel beyond the limits of the town in his capacity as a police officer, he shall be entitled to his actual expenses, to be allowed and paid as is now provided by law for other expenses in criminal cases. 
(d)  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as prohibiting a police officer of the town from claiming and receiving any reward which may be offered for the arrest and detention of any offender against the criminal laws of this or any other state or nation. 
(Code 1973, § 22-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-138; territorial jurisdiction of town, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-250. 
Sec. 21-6. - Duty hours. 
    The members of the police department shall be on duty at such times of the day or night as the town manager may require. While on duty, they shall be under the control of the town manager. 
(Code 1973, § 22-6) 
Sec. 21-7. - Encouraging resistance to an officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to encourage or counsel resistance to any officer or by threats or force intimidate or impede or attempt to intimidate or impede the town sergeant or any police officer in making arrests or in the discharge of his duties. 
(Code 1973, § 22-7) 
State Law reference- Obstructing justice by threats or force, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-460. 
Sec. 21-8. - Uniform and badge to be worn. 
    Each member of the police department shall wear while on duty such wearing apparel as is necessary to perform specific functions nor incidental to routine patrol. The officers while in uniform, shall wear a badge of office, along with a medal with the name of office engraved thereon, upon his outer garment and in plain view; but in the event that a uniform is not worn, a badge of office shall at all times be carried on the officer, along with a medal with the name of the office engraved thereon. 
(Code 1973, § 22-8; Ord. No. 176 , 7-13-2016) 
Sec. 21-9. - Impersonating officer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely assume or exercise the functions, powers, duties and privileges of or falsely assume or pretend to be the town sergeant or any other peace officer of the town. 
(Code 1973, § 22-9) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-174. 
Sec. 21-10. - Other employment. 
    No regular police officer employed by the town shall engage in any occupation, business or calling which would render him unfit or in any way hinder him in the discharge of his duties to the town. 
(Code 1973, § 22-10) 
Sec. 21-10.1. - Auxiliary police force. 
(a)  Pursuant to Code of Virginia § 15.2-1731, as amended, for the further preservation of the public peace, safety and good order of the community, the town hereby establishes an auxiliary police force, which will have all the powers and authority and all the immunities of fulltime law-enforcement officers; if such forces have met the training requirements established by the Department of Criminal Justice Services under Code of Virginia § 9.1-101, as amended. 
(b)  The police chief is hereby authorized to appoint as auxiliary police officers as many persons of good character as he deems necessary, not to exceed six (6). The chief of police is also authorized to prescribe the uniform, organization, and such rules as he deems necessary for the operation of the auxiliary police force. 
(c)  The auxiliary police officers may be called into service as provided in Code of Virginia § 15.2-1734, as amended. In addition, the members of the auxiliary police force who have been trained in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia § 15.2-1731, as amended, may be called into service by the chief of police, or his designee, to aid and assist regular police officers in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 148, 11-9-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 149, adopted Nov. 9, 2011, enacted provisions intended for codification as § 21-11.1 of this chapter. To facilitate indexing, said provisions have been redesignated as § 21-10.1. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 21-11. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm system means any device or system which transmits a signal visibly, audibly, electronically, mechanically or by any combination of these methods which indicates a hazard or occurrence requiring urgent attention and to which police are expected to respond. The term "alarm system" shall not include a personal, direct telephone call requesting emergency services from a person at the premises in question. 
    Alarm system user and user mean the occupant or owner of the premises which is protected by the alarm system. 
    False alarm means any alarm signal communicated to the police communications center which is not reasonably believed to be in response to actual or threatened criminal activity. False alarms include negligently activated signals; signals which are the result of faulty, malfunctioning or improperly installed or maintained equipment; and signals which are purposely activated to summons police personnel in non-emergency situations. False alarms shall not include signals activated by unusually severe weather conditions or other causes which are identified and determined by the chief of police or designee to be beyond the control of the user. 
    Negligently activated means the doing of an act where ordinary care suggests that the act should not have been done at all or that it should have been done in some other way. 
(Ord. No. 52, 8-4-99) 
Sec. 21-12. - Duties of alarm system users. 
    All alarm system users must register with the chief of police prior to hooking up an alarm system. All existing alarm systems must be registered with the chief of police within thirty (30) days of the adoption of this article. 
    It shall be the responsibility of alarm system users to instruct employees or others who may have occasion to activate an alarm that alarm systems are to be activated only in emergency situations to summons an immediate police response. Alarm system users shall also instruct appropriate employees as to the operation of the alarm system, including setting, activating and resetting the alarm. The user shall be responsible for maintaining the security system in proper working order. 
(Ord. No. 52, 8-4-99) 
Sec. 21-13. - Service fees-Established; termination of response. 
(a)  Schedule of fees. The second through tenth false alarm originating from any premises within a ninety-day period will result in the appropriate service fee being imposed upon the alarm user which must be paid within thirty (30) days after billing. The service fee shall be imposed in accordance with the following schedule: 
False Alarm Fee Second $10.00 Third 15.00 Fourth 20.00 Fifth 25.00 Sixth 35.00 Seventh 50.00 Eighth 60.00 Ninth 75.00  
(b)  Discontinuance of service. The tenth false alarm originating from any premises in a ninety-day period will result in the alarm user being notified by the chief of police or designee that all emergency response by the police department, based on alarm activation, shall cease upon receipt of the written notice. 
(c)  Reinstatement of service. Any service which has been discontinued shall not be reinstated until it has been inspected by an alarm company licensed to do business in the commonwealth, which company shall certify the system has been repaired and is found to be in a reliable status. 
    If the false alarm occurred through human negligence rather than mechanical failure, reinstatement shall not be permitted until the user, the user's employees and all others having access to the system have completed a training program satisfactory to the chief of police or designee. In addition to such written certification to the chief of police or designee, a reinstatement fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), payable to the town, must accompany the request for reinstatement. The inspection, repair and recertification of any alarm system shall be accomplished at the alarm user's expense. 
(Ord. No. 52, 8-4-99) 
Sec. 21-14. - Same-Exceptions. 
    The service and reinstatement fees of this article shall not be applied to any alarm system used, operated or installed in any premises or place owned, leased, occupied or under the control of the United States government, the commonwealth or any of its political subdivisions, to the town or any of its political subdivisions or to the county school board or any officer, agent or employee of such governmental agencies while acting or employed in their official capacities. All other requirements, including termination of service, shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 52, 8-4-99) 
Sec. 21-15. - Payment of fees. 
    The chief of police or designee shall certify to the treasurer the name of the user, the address from which alarms subject to penalty emanated and the amount due the town on the last day of each month. The treasurer shall cause billing to be sent and shall in turn notify the chief of police or designee whether any account is more than thirty (30) days in arrears. Any account more than thirty (30) days in arrears shall be subjected to a termination of response and the reinstatement fee specified in this article before service is restored. 
(Ord. No. 52, 8-4-99) 
ARTICLE III. - REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES 

Sec. 21-16. - Reimbursement of expenses incurred in responding to DUI incident and other accidents or traffic incidents. 
(a)  A person convicted of violating any of the following provisions shall be liable for restitution at the time of sentencing or in a separate civil action for reasonable expenses incurred by the town, including by the police department, or by any volunteer fire or rescue squad, or by any combination of the foregoing, when providing an appropriate emergency response to any accident or incident related to such violation: 
(1)  Pursuant to the Code of Virginia, 1950, (as amended), provisions § 18.2-51.4, 18.2-266, 18.2-266.1, 29.1-738, 29.1-738.02, or a similar ordinance, when such operation of a motor vehicle, engine, train or watercraft while so impaired is the proximate cause of the accident or incident. 
(2)  Pursuant to the Code of Virginia, 1950, (as amended), provisions of Article 7 (§ 46.2-852 et seq.) of Charter 8 of Title 46.2 relating to reckless driving, when such reckless driving is the proximate cause of the accident or incident; 
(3)  Pursuant to the Code of Virginia, 1950, (as amended), provisions of Article 1 (§ 46.2-300 et seq.) of Chapter 3 of Title 46.2 relating to driving without a license or driving with a suspended or revoked license; and 
(4)  Pursuant to the Code of Virginia, 1950, (as amended), provisions of § 46.2-894 relating to improperly leaving the scene of an accident. 
(b)  Personal liability under this section for reasonable expenses of an appropriate emergency response shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) in the aggregate for a particular accident or incident occurring in the town. In determining the "reasonable expenses" the town may bill a flat fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or a minute by minute accounting of the actual costs incurred. As used in this section, "appropriate emergency response" includes all costs of providing law-enforcement, fire-fighting, rescue and emergency medical services. The court may order as restitution the reasonable expenses incurred by the town for fire-fighting, rescue and emergency medical services. The provisions of this section shall not preempt or limit any remedy available to the commonwealth, to the town or to any volunteer rescue squad to recover the reasonable expenses of an emergency response to an accident or incident not involving impaired driving, operation of a vehicle or other conduct as set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 97, 2-8-2006; Ord. No. 112, 2-14-2007) 
Chapter 22 - SOLID WASTE AND WEEDS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 12; junkyards, car lots and automobile graveyards, Ch. 13; nuisances, Ch. 17; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 28; debris, trash and rubbish in cemetery, § 8-15; rubbish and waste matter in junkyard, car lot or automobile graveyard, § 13-9; throwing or depositing certain substances upon highway, § 15-16. 
State Law reference- Virginia Waste Management Act, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1400 et seq.; removal of trash, garbage, weeds, etc., from property, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-11; contracts for garbage and refuse pickup and disposal services, waste recovery facilities, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-28.02; ordinances requiring delivery of garbage, trash and refuse to certain facilities, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-28.03; regulation of garbage and refuse pickup and disposal services, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-28.1; municipal collection and disposal of refuse, regulation of disposal facilities, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-857; mailing of summons for violation of trash ordinance, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-76.2; dumping trash, etc., on highway, right-of-way or private property, Code of Virginia, §§ 33.1-346, 33.1-346.1; dump creating fire hazard to public bridge, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-347. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Ashes and clinkers means the residue from fires used for cooking and heating. 
    Combustible rubbish means paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, wood and excelsior, yard trimmings, wood furniture, bedding and other materials of a similar nature. 
    Garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Industrial refuse means the solid wastes resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing and construction operations, such as food processing wastes, boiler house cinders, lumber scraps and shavings and similar materials. 
    Market refuse means the waste from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Noncombustible rubbish means metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, glass, crockery and other materials of a similar nature. 
    Street refuse means street sweepings, dirt and leaves in the streets. 
(Code 1973, § 13-1) 
Sec. 22-2. - Depositing garbage, etc., on streets or premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw into the streets or sidewalks or on private premises any dead carcasses, rubbish, newspapers, handbills, dirt, filth, shavings, manure, offal, ashes, vegetables, fruit, fruit skins, broken glass, tacks, tin cans or any other articles or substances or things calculated to render the streets or premises unclean, unsightly or unsafe to any person or vehicle using the streets or liable to injuriously affect the health of the community. 
(Code 1973, § 13-2) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 22-3. - Dumping garbage, etc., at unauthorized locations. 
    Nothing shall be removed from a private premises and deposited within the town limits at any place except such as may be designated by the town manager; nor shall anything be dumped into a town provided container or private dumpster without first having consent from the owner, renter or provider of such dumpster or container. 
(Code 1973, § 13-3; Ord. No. 50, 3-10-99) 
Sec. 22-4. - Bringing garbage or trash into town. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person outside the corporate limits of the town to transport garbage or trash into the corporate limits of the town for collection by the town crews. 
(Code 1973, § 13-4; Ord. No. 156, 6-25-2012 ) 
Sec. 22-5. - Tampering with garbage containers, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, examine into, or remove from garbage containers, boxes, etc., the contents therein set out by the owner, or employee of the owner, for collection by the town or by private contractor. 
(Code 1973, § 13-5; Ord. No. 50, 3-10-99) 
Secs. 22-6-22-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 47, adopted July 8, 1998, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. The former Art. II, §§ 22-21-22-34, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1973, §§ 13-6-13-12, 13-12.1, 13-13, 13-14; Ord. No. 4, adopted Aug. 8, 1991; and Ord. No. 12, adopted May 13, 1992. 

Sec. 22-21. - Compliance with chapter prerequisite to collection. 
    Any refuse put out for collection which does not comply with this chapter shall not be collected by the town collection crew but shall be removed by the owner or tenant. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98) 
Sec. 22-22. - Preparation of refuse. 
(a)  In business area. In any business area in the town all paper cartons shall be folded flat. Where there are large quantities of loose paper, sufficient cartons may be left intact to hold such paper. 
(b)  In residential area. In any residential area, garbage shall be bagged and tied before being placed in the refuse container provided by the town. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98) 
Sec. 22-23. - Industrial refuse. 
    No industrial or bio-hazardous refuse shall be collected by the town collection crew. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98; Ord. No. 156, 6-25-12 ; Ord. No. 157, 6-25-2012 ) 
Sec. 22-24. - Containers required. 
    All garbage and rubbish out for collection by town trucks shall be placed in containers provided by the town. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98) 
Sec. 22-25. - Placement of containers at collection site and removal of same therefrom. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner and user of a town refuse container, the contents of which are to be collected by the town forces, to: 
(1)  Place the container at the curbside in the public right-of-way, alley or designated pick up area, so that there is no danger of the container being overturned and so that there is sufficient clearance to accommodate town collection equipment and pedestrians. 
(2)  For residents receiving regular once weekly refuse collection, place collection containers at the collection site no later than 7:00 a.m. on the day of collection and not earlier than 5:00 p.m. on the night prior to the day of collection. Placement of containers at the collection site prior to 5:00 p.m. on the night prior to the day of collection or failure to remove containers by 12:00 midnight of the collection day shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(3)  Remove all emptied containers from the alley, curbside, street or sidewalk as soon as practicable after they have been emptied, but in no case later than 12:00 midnight of the collection day. 
(4)  Collections containers shall be located five (5) feet behind the building line, or screened so as to not be visible from the street except during the times prescribed for placement for collection. This provision applies to all residential and commercial locations. Where placement as described herein is not possible, an alternate location may be designated by the director of public works, or his designee. 
(5)  For those designated shopping centers and businesses receiving collection services on a regular three-day-per-week schedule, place collection containers at the collection site no earlier than 5:00 p.m. on the day preceding collection, nor later than 6:00 a.m. on the day of collection. 
(6)  Recyclables may be placed out for collection no earlier than 5:00 p.m. of the day preceding collection, nor later than 7:00 a.m. of the day of collection. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98) 
Sec. 22-26. - Bulk containers for residential areas. 
(a)  The regulations set forth in this section shall be administered by the town manager. The director of public works and the fire chief shall assist the town manager as provided herein. 
(b)  All bulk containers in residential areas shall require current permits as issued by the town manager. When property owners or managers propose new constructions or changes in use requiring the installation of bulk containers, they shall submit a proposed site plan to the office of the building official. The permit application and site plan, along with such fees as specified by the town council, shall be submitted before the installation is begun. 
(c)  The town manager shall recommend approval of the installation, subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  The bulk containers will not be located on any town property, right-of-way or easement. 
(2)  The bulk containers will be accessible for removal, transportation or emptying from a public right-of-way. 
(3)  The proposed location will not violate any fire or building code, or zoning ordinance. 
(4)  The base on which the bulk container is located will be firm (concrete or equal) and cleanable. 
(5)  The bulk container will be located not less than ten (10) feet from any building, fire escape or doorway. 
(6)  The bulk container will be located behind the building line. 
(7)  The bulk container will not displace a required parking space. 
(8)  Bulk containers may require screening if adjacent to a residence. 
(d)  The town manager may seek independent verification of data set forth in the site plan and may disapprove a plan if he cannot verify compliance with the requirements of subsection (c) above. 
(e)  When bulk containers have been installed at existing structures prior to April 1, 1988, the owner or manager of such structure will obtain a bulk container permit in accordance with the provision in subsection (c) above. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98) 
Sec. 22-27. - Preparation and removal of yard trimmings. 
    Yard and tree trimmings shall be collected by town collection crews; provided, that the yard trimmings, such as grass clippings, hedge or shrub clippings and other small items of a similar nature, are placed in suitable containers or plastic bags not exceeding fifty (50) pounds in weight, and tree trimmings not exceeding two (2) inches in diameter and five (5) feet long are placed in a neat pile. Yard and tree trimmings shall be placed on the grass plots or front portions of lawns where there is no grass plot or a service alley being used by the town. Collection by town crews will be made once a week and additional days as required will be designated by the town manager. Complete trees or tree trimmings resulting from pruning or tree surgery must be removed by the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98) 
Sec. 22-28. - Fall leaves. 
    During the months of September through December, leaves placed in neat and orderly piles shall be removed by the town trucks from grass plots or front portions of lawns where there are no grass plots. No leaves shall be placed on the sidewalks or in the streets or gutters. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98) 
Sec. 22-29. - Cardboard-Collection generally. 
(a)  The mandatory separation and collection of cardboard from other solid waste applies to business/commercial establishments within the corporate limits of the town. 
(b)  The cardboard collected by the town will become the property of the town who will be responsible for its recycling. Private haulers will be permitted to collect cardboard from commercial establishments providing (i) the cardboard is being recycled at a local recycler and (ii) the private hauler provides the commercial establishment with a suitable cardboard collection bin as outlined in subsection (c). Private haulers will be responsible for providing accurate weight records of the cardboard collected to the town at its request. 
(c)  All cardboard shall be broken down and stacked in bundles and placed inside a closed, non-porous collection bin of not over four (4) cubic yards in capacity. Containers shall be made of metal, plastic, or other suitable material and shall have a tight fitting cover. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98; Ord. No. 99, 6-15-2006) 
Sec. 22-30. - Same-Collection site. 
    The bundles of cardboard are to be placed at a site where the other refuse is picked up or a location that is readily accessible for town employees to pick up. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98) 
Sec. 22-31. - Same-Collection frequency. 
    The town manager is authorized to provide a regular collection schedule for the pick up of the bundles of cardboard from commercial establishments. Where sufficient volume is generated at certain establishments more frequent collections will be authorized and scheduled. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98) 
Sec. 22-31.1. - Monthly service charge-Sanitation fee. 
    For garbage and recycling refuse collection and removal service, the occupant of each dwelling unit and business unit in the town shall pay a rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per month, and this service charge shall be billed to each user monthly with the water and sewer service or other method, if any, and payable therewith. The occupant of each dwelling unit shall be entitled to one pick up of garbage and refuse each week and business pick up will be determined by the director of public works. Trash other than household garbage may be removed by town employees if requested and approved for removal by the town manager when placed at curbside. 
( Ord. No. 156, 6-25-2012 ) 
State Law reference- Local recycling and waste disposal; powers; penalties, Code of Virginia § 15.2-928. 
Sec. 22-32. - Cardboard-Penalty for noncompliance. 
(a)  Before issuing a criminal citation for an infraction hereunder, warning notices shall be given to the responsible lessee or owner as follows: 
(1)  First violation: The town manager and/or representative shall issue a warning to the responsible party. 
(2)  Second violation: This warning notice shall be sent to the person responsible by certified mail to the address where the violation occurred. 
(3)  Third violation: A criminal citation will be issued and this violation shall be punished as a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(b)  The following shall apply with respect to infraction: 
(1)  Failure to abate the cited violation at the time of a subsequent infraction shall cause the violation to be treated as a repeat violation. 
(2)  Any individual or corporate owner who receives a citation and who wishes to stand trial shall not receive additional citations until the court rules on the citation for which the defendant is standing trial. 
(3)  In cases where the town manager has determined that extreme danger exists to persons or property regarding storage of the cardboard bundles the warning notice shall be dispensed with and the town manager shall obtain a court order to take corrective action. However nothing shall be construed to prohibit the town manager from taking what action he deems appropriate to protect the public health and safety both under the laws of the town and the commonwealth. 
(4)  The town manager or the manager's representative shall have authority to enforce all the provisions of sections 22-21 through 22-32. 
(Ord. No. 47, 7-8-98; Ord. No. 156, 6-25-2012 ) 
Secs. 22-33-22-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONDITION OF PREMISES[3] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 22-46. - Weeds, brush, etc., on property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have, keep, maintain, cause or permit upon any land or premises any grass, weeds, brush or other vegetable matter detrimental to the health, comfort or general welfare of the inhabitants of the town. 
(Code 1973, § 13-15) 
Sec. 22-47. - Weeds, etc., encroaching on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any weeds, thistles, brushes or plants to overhang or encroach upon any sidewalk adjoining his property. 
(Code 1973, § 13-16) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 22-48. - Cutting grass, weeds. 
    The owners of vacant developed or undeveloped property therein shall cut the grass, weeds and other foreign growth on such property or any part thereof at such time or times as the council shall prescribe; or may, whenever the council deems it necessary, after reasonable notice, have such grass, weeds or other foreign growth cut by its agents or employees, in which event, the cost and expenses thereof shall be chargeable to and paid by the owner of such property and may be collected by the town as taxes and levies are collected. 
Sec. 22-49. - Reserved.

Chapter 23 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of council as to streets, alleys, sidewalks, etc., § 10 et seq. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; advertising, Ch. 3; buildings, Ch. 6; cable television, Ch. 7; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 15; noise control, Ch. 16; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 19; planning, Ch. 20; subdivisions, Ch. 24; taxicabs, Ch. 26; trees and shrubs, Ch. 27; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 28; conditions on street occupancy by cable television company, § 7-17; streets and sidewalks near junkyards, car lots and automobile graveyards, § 13-12; curfew for minors, § 18-7 et seq.; house numbers, § 18-24; loitering, § 18-29; removing sand, rock, etc., from streets, § 18-39; depositing solid waste on streets, § 22-2; weeds, etc., encroaching on sidewalks, § 22-47; streets in subdivisions, § 24-76 et seq.; location of sewer, § 28-133; widening of highways and streets, § 29-52. 
State Law reference- Authority of town to lay off streets, walks or alleys and to permit the temporary use of streets for other than public purposes, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-14(1), (9); limited access streets, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-16; assessments for local improvements, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-239 et seq.; municipal streets and alleys generally, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-363 et seq., 15.1-888 et seq.; franchises, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-894; state highway plat book, Code of Virginia, § 17-69.1; state highway system, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-25 et seq.; pipelines and other works in streets and alleys, Code of Virginia, § 56-257. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Obstructing streets, sidewalks, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or interfere with the passage of persons on any sidewalk, street, railroad platform or crossing or to obstruct the entrance to any public building, business or church. Gates shall not be constructed so that they open outward over any street, alley or sidewalk. No assembly shall be held on any street, alley or public ground without a written permit from the mayor. This section shall not apply to railroads blocking streets or sidewalks. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to obstruct or interfere in any way with the passage of persons along the public driveways and sidewalks of the town for the purpose of inducing them to purchase any article or thing or to enter into any shop, store or stall, any hotel, boardinghouse, restaurant or like establishment, or to importune passersby to make any such purchase or to enter such establishment, or in any disorderly or undue manner to solicit trade, custom or patronage in or along the public highways of the town. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or allow to be placed or to continue the accumulation of leaves, grass clippings, sticks, dirt or refuse, etc., from their house, business, yard, or other property onto a public street, a sidewalk, the grass strip between a paved sidewalk and a street, or into a storm sewer inlet or on an area that pedestrians would be expected to use as a public right-of-way. Such refuse shall be gathered into containers and collected with other refuse; provided, however, that this provision shall not apply to the accumulation of leaves placed along the edge of the roadway in the public right-of-way during special collection periods designated by the town for collection of leaves. 
(d)  Each day the condition exists constitutes a separate offense. Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 23-1; Ord. No. 133, 12-8-2010) 
State Law reference- Obstructions on streets and alleys, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-893. 
Sec. 23-2. - Parking of buses, trailers and certain trucks restricted. 
(a)  No person shall park or cause, or permit to be parked, any motor passenger bus, camping, boating or utility trailer, or other trailer or any truck with a carrying capacity of one (1) ton or greater, on any street or alley or other public place in the town on Sundays, holidays or on weekdays between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., except for the purpose of loading and unloading. 
(b)  A conditional permit shall be acquired at the town treasurer's office to park any trailer, tractor-trailer or similar vehicle, in a business or manufacturing area, on town streets. 
(c)  The cost for the permit shall be assessed at one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month, per vehicle. The person acquiring the permit is responsible to insure that the street is kept clean and free of debris. Recreational vehicles and camping trailers, in residential areas, are exempt, providing they are not kept on the street for longer than a seven-day period, during any calendar year. 
(d)  Violation of this section shall result in a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each offense. Each day shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 6-14-90) 
Sec. 23-3. - Coasting on sidewalks, etc., in business district. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to coast or slide on any sidewalk or on any street in the business section of the town by means of any sled, coaster, wagon or other contrivance. 
(Code 1973, § 23-2) 
Sec. 23-4. - Playing ball or golf on streets, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to play ball or golf on any street or public property without the consent of the mayor or the council. 
(Code 1973, § 23-3) 
Sec. 23-5. - Playing on streets or sidewalks. 
    No person shall play on any street within the town that is designated for vehicular travel. No person shall use on a street where play is prohibited roller skates, toys or other devices on wheels or runners except bicycles and motorcycles. No person shall use roller skates, toys, or other devices on wheels or runners including bicycles and motorcycles on any sidewalks within the business district of the town, Longwood College, or any other area so designated by the council. Skating or skateboarding on other sidewalks in the town will be prohibited after 10:00 p.m. 
(Code 1973, § 23-4) 
Sec. 23-6. - Removal of snow from sidewalks on certain streets. 
(a)  The tenant, owner or occupant or any person having the care of any building or lot bordering on any of the following streets shall be required to remove all snow from the sidewalks abutting such property within six (6) hours after the snow shall have ceased falling, unless the snow shall have fallen during the night or on Sunday in which case it shall be removed by 12:00 noon the day following: 
(1)  High Street, between North Street and Main Street. 
(2)  Main Street, between Robeson Street and Depot Street (Norfolk and Western right-of-way). 
(3)  Third Street, between North Street and Bridge Street. 
(b)  Any person failing to remove the snow shall, in addition to the fine imposed, be liable for the cost of the removal by the town. 
(Code 1973, § 23-5) 
Sec. 23-7. - Placing merchandise, etc., on sidewalks, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place on or suffer to be placed on or to suspend over any sidewalk, street or alley any merchandise, goods, wares, ice cream cans or containers, pop or beer cases, chicken crates, packing cases or boxes, coal, wood or other fuel or anything of a similar character so as to interfere with the free passage of persons using the street, sidewalk or alley. No wood or other fuel shall be cut, split or sawed on any street, sidewalk or alley without a permit from the town manager. 
(Code 1973, § 23-6) 
Sec. 23-8. - Unguarded opening on or near street or sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep open any cellar door, grating or cover to any vault or fail to properly protect or guard all openings on or within six (6) feet of any street, alley, sidewalk or highway. 
(Code 1973, § 23-7) 
Sec. 23-9. - Awnings over sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain awnings unless all parts of the awning shall be elevated at least seven (7) feet above the surface of the sidewalk and at least eighteen (18) inches back from the edge of the curb, and the roof or covering shall be made of duck, canvas or other suitable material supported by iron frames or brackets firmly and securely fastened to the building, without any posts or other device that will obstruct the sidewalk or hinder or interfere with the free passage of pedestrians thereon and then only upon obtaining a permit from the town manager's office. 
(Code 1973, § 23-8) 
Sec. 23-10. - Permit for sale of fruit, vegetables, etc., from stand or vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or keep any stand for the sale of fruits, vegetables or other substances or commodities on any sidewalk, street or alley or to use or occupy any part of a street or alley with any vehicle for the sale therefrom of any article without written permission from the mayor. 
(Code 1973, § 23-9) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 23-11. - Discharging water on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit any waterspout, trough, gutter or balcony extending from any building owned or leased by him to discharge or conduct water on the surface of any sidewalk. All such water shall be conducted under the sidewalk in accordance with plans and specifications of the town manager and under his direction. 
(Code 1973, § 23-10) 
Cross reference- Water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 28. 
Sec. 23-12. - Writing, scattering handbills, etc., on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to scatter waste, or to place paste, paint or writing on any sidewalk, street or alley without the consent of the mayor or to leave any paper removed or coming from billboards on any street or sidewalk or to scatter showbills, handbills or other advertising on the sidewalks, streets or alleys. 
(Code 1973, § 23-11) 
Cross reference- Advertising, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 23-13. - Bicycle helmets. 
(a)  Every person fourteen (14) years of age or younger shall wear a protective helmet that meets the standards promulgated by the American National Standards Institute or the Snell Memorial Foundation whenever riding or being carried on a bicycle on any highway as defined in Code of Virginia § 46.2-100, as amended, sidewalk or public bicycle path. 
(b)  Violation of such ordinance shall be punishable by a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). However, such fine shall be suspended (i) for first-time offenders, and (ii) for violators who, subsequent to the violation but prior to imposition of the fine, purchase helmets of the type required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 34, 12-13-95) 
Secs. 23-14-23-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 23-31. - Constructing curbs and gutters. 
    The policy of the town concerning the construction of curbs and gutters within its corporate limits shall be to construct the same at no expense to the adjacent property owners; but wherever curbs and gutters are constructed, construction shall be insofar as practicable, an orderly program to tie in future constructions and already existing curbs and gutters so that the same shall be for an entire block or one (1) side of a block within a block when it is practical to do so. Where adjacent property owners are willing to voluntarily share in the cost of construction of curbs and gutters by making voluntary payments on some portion of the cost thereof to the town, the town will consider accepting contributions from adjacent property owners. The council reserves the right to pass on all such projects on the basis of their necessity, and such curbs and gutters so built under this program shall adhere to the policy heretofore set out. No curbs and gutters shall be built with aid from adjacent property owners unless funds are available for that purpose to meet the town's agreed portion thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 23-12) 
Sec. 23-32. - Sidewalk and terrace grade. 
    All sidewalks and terraces, where practicable, shall have a uniform grade of two and one-half (21/2) percent from the inside of the walk to the outside of the curb unless otherwise provided by resolution of the council. 
(Code 1973, § 23-13) 
Sec. 23-33. - Curb lines. 
    The curb lines shall be parallel with the lot lines and at such distances therefrom as established by the town engineer. 
(Code 1973, § 23-14) 
Sec. 23-34. - Permit required to erect steps to sidewalk, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any stairs or steps to the first or second floor of any building on any part of any sidewalk, street or alley or to construct or build a stairway or passageway to any cellar or basement by occupying any part of the sidewalk, street or alley or to enclose any portion of the same with a railing without having first obtained permission, by resolution, of the council. 
(Code 1973, § 23-15) 
Sec. 23-35. - Excavations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation in any street, alley or public place or within ten (10) feet of any sidewalk, street, alley or public place except in accordance with the provisions of the following paragraphs. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than a duly authorized officer or employee of the town to make any excavation in any street, alley, highway or public property or to dig up or uncover so as to expose to frost any of the mains or water pipes of the town, except after securing the consent of the council or the town manager thereto. In making such excavations, the planks, paving stones, earth and other materials shall be deposited and placed in such manner as to occasion the least inconvenience to the public and to permit the passage of water along the gutter. All such excavations and any excavations near any street, alley, highway or public property shall be so guarded at all times as to prevent injury to persons and animals using the streets, alleys and highways or public property. Red lights shall be so placed at night as to give warning of all excavations and ditches. The contractor and the person for whom the excavation has been made shall relieve the town of any responsibility for any accident or damage that may be caused by the work in question. 
(c)  In refilling excavations, the earth shall be laid in layers and each layer packed to prevent settlement and the street, alley or highway placed in as good condition as before to the satisfaction of the town manager. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall apply to the making of any and all excavations made pursuant to the provisions of this chapter in any street, alley or highway by any person other than a duly authorized officer or employee of the town. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dig into or in any manner break any sidewalk, curb, pavement, street, alley or public ground without replacing the same in as good condition as found. 
(Code 1973, § 23-16) 
Chapter 24 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14; planning, Ch. 20; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 23; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 28; zoning, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Codification of subdivision ordinance, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3; land subdivision and development, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-465 et seq.; Virginia Public Records Act, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-76 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Administrator means the representative of the governing body who has been appointed to serve as the agent of the governing body in approving subdivision plats. 
    Alley means a permanent service way providing a secondary means of access to abutting properties. 
    Approve means the word "approve" shall be considered to be followed by the words "or disapproval." 
    Block means an area enclosed by adjacent and usually by intersecting streets. 
    Building lane means the distance which a building is from the front lot line or front boundary line. 
    Commission means the planning commission of Farmville, Virginia. 
    Cul-de-sac means a street with only one (1) outlet and having an appropriate turnaround for a safe and convenient reverse traffic movement. 
    Developer means an owner of property being subdivided, whether or not represented by an agent. 
    Distance, area means measurements in a horizontal plane. 
    Easement means a grant by a property owner of the use of land for a specific purpose. 
    Engineer means an engineer licensed by the commonwealth. 
    G.I.S . means geographic information system. 
    Governing body means the town council. 
    Health official means the health director or sanitarian serving the town. 
    Highway engineer means the resident engineer employed by the state department of transportation. 
    Jurisdiction means the area or territory subject to the legislative control of the governing body. 
    Lot means a numbered and recorded portion of a subdivision intended for transfer of ownership or for building development for a single building and its accessory building. The word "lot" includes the word "parcel." 
    Lot, corner, means a lot abutting upon two (2) or more streets at their intersection; the shortest side fronting on a street shall be considered the front of the lot and the longest side fronting on a street shall be considered the side of the lot. 
    Lot, depth of, means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines. 
    Lot, double frontage, means an interior lot having frontage on two (2) streets. 
    Lot, interior, means a lot other than a corner lot. 
    Lot of record means a lot which has been recorded in the office of the clerk of the appropriate court. 
    Lot, width of, means the mean horizontal distance between the side lot lines. 
    Plat includes the terms "map," "plan," "plot," "replat" or "replot"; a map or plan of a tract or parcel of land which is to be or which has been subdivided. When used as a verb, plat is synonymous with subdivide. 
    Property means any tract, lot, parcel or several of the same collected together for the purpose of subdividing. 
    Street means the principal means of access to abutting properties. 
    Street, major, means any existing or future street designated as a major street on the adopted plan of land use and major thoroughfares or heavily traveled thoroughfare or highway that carries a large volume of through traffic or anticipated traffic exceeding five hundred (500) vehicles per day. 
    Street, minor, means a street that is used primarily as a means of public access to the abutting properties with anticipated traffic of less than five hundred (500) vehicles per day. 
    Street or alley, public use of, means the unrestricted use of a specified area or right-of-way for ingress and egress to two (2) or more abutting properties. 
    Street, service drive, means a public right-of-way generally parallel and contiguous to a major highway, primarily designated to promote safety by eliminating promiscuous ingress and egress to the right-of-way by providing safe and orderly points of access to the highway. 
    Street width means the total width of the strip of land dedicated or reserved for public travel, including roadway, curbs, gutters, sidewalks and planting strips. 
    Subdivide means to divide any tract, parcel or lot of land into two (2) or more parts; except, that the administrator may permit the separation of one (1) parcel from a tract of land without complying with all requirements of this chapter if it is: 
(1)  Not in conflict with the general meaning and purpose of this chapter. 
(2)  No new streets are required to serve the parcel. 
(3)  Meets or exceeds all zoning requirements. 
(4)  Not less than one-hundred-fifty-foot frontage. 
(5)  Signed by the administrator as required in section 24-37, (paragraph (1)a).
