(2)  College structures may be erected to a height of one hundred twenty-five (125) feet from grade; provided, that required front, side and rear yards shall be increased one (1) foot for each foot in height over thirty-five (35) feet. 
(3)  Church spires, belfries, cupolas, municipal water towers, chimneys, flues, flagpoles, television antennas and radio aerials are exempt. Parapet walls may be up to four (4) feet above the height of the building on which the walls rest. 
(4)  Accessory buildings over one (1) story in height shall be at least ten (10) feet from any lot line. All accessory buildings shall be less than the main building in height. 
(Code 1973, § 29-32) 
Sec. 29-128. - Corner lots. 
(a)  Of the two (2) sides of a corner lot in a residential district R-2 the front shall be deemed to be the shortest of the two (2) sides fronting on streets. 
(b)  The side yard on the side facing the side street shall be twenty-five (25) feet or more for both main and accessory buildings. 
(c)  For subdivisions platted after February 18, 1971, each corner lot shall have a minimum width at the setback line of one hundred (100) feet or more. 
(Code 1973, § 29-33) 
Secs. 29-129-29-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT R-3 

Sec. 29-146. - Statement of intent. 
    Residential district R-3 encompasses high-density residential areas, both existing and planned, as well as certain compatible public, semipublic and very limited commercial land uses. The following regulations are designed to stabilize, protect and promote this type of development. This district should provide a suitable environment for persons desiring the amenities of apartment living and the convenience of being closest to shopping and employment centers and other community facilities. 
(Code 1973, § 29-34) 
Sec. 29-147. - Uses. 
    Only one (1) building and its accessory buildings may be erected on any lot or parcel of land in residential district R-3. Structures to be erected or land to be used shall be for one (1) or more of the following uses: 
(1)  Single-family dwellings. 
(2)  Two-family dwellings or two (2) housekeeping units. 
(3)  Multiple-family dwellings with a conditional use permit. 
(4)  Rooming and boarding houses. 
(5)  Reserved. 
(6)  University related facilities, with a conditional use permit. 
(7)  Elementary, intermediate and secondary schools, both public and private, with a conditional use permit. 
(8)  Day schools and kindergartens with conditional use permit. 
(9)  Churches, lodges, armories and other public and semipublic facilities, including hospitals, excepting veterinary hospitals and hospitals specializing in the care and treatment of mental illnesses, narcotic addicts or alcoholics, unwed mothers and those about to become mothers out of wedlock. A conditional use permit may be required for these uses. 
(10)  Rest, convalescent or nursing homes but not penal or mental institutions. 
(11)  Parks and playgrounds. 
(12)  Professional offices. 
(13)  Home occupations conducted by the occupant. 
(14)  Off-street parking as required by this chapter. 
(15)  Accessory uses and structures customarily incident to any user permitted by this section, such as servants' quarters, greenhouses or workshops; provided, that none shall be conducted for gain and that no accessory buildings shall be inhabited by other than those who are employees of the owner, leasor or tenant of the premises. No accessory building may be closer than two (2) feet to any property line and no overhang may project closer than one (1) foot to any property line. 
(16)  Private garage on the same lot with the building not maintained for the service of the public or operated or conducted for commercial or industrial use, but no such private garage shall be hereafter located or erected on any residential block closer to the street than the setback line for the residence on that street or side street. 
(17)  Private group garages, not exceeding four (4), fronting on alleys; provided, that no commercial repair work is done; further provided, that it must be set back not less than five (5) feet from alley. 
(18)  Public utilities, including poles, lines, distribution transformers, pipes, meters, and other facilities necessary for the provision and maintenance of public utilities, including water and sewerage facilities. Electrical transmission lines and substations are excluded. 
(19)  Business or identification signs not exceeding six (6) square feet in area per side and not more than two (2) sides, no part of which shall be nearer than five (5) feet to any town property line. 
(20)  Church bulletin boards and church identification signs for church activities, only not exceeding twelve (12) square feet in area no part of which shall be nearer than five (5) feet to any town property line. 
(21)  Temporary real estate signs not over six (6) square feet in area no part of which shall be nearer than five (5) feet to any property line and used only to advertise the premises upon which erected. 
(Code 1973, § 29-35; Ord. No. 119, 6-11-2008; Ord. No. 120, 1-14-2009; Ord. No. 186 , 12-6-2017) 
Sec. 29-148. - Minimum area. 
(a)  The minimum lot area in a residential district R-3 shall be five thousand (5,000) square feet, plus two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet for each additional dwelling unit under one (1) roof for lots served by public water and sewer; however, the overall density shall not exceed ten (10) dwelling units per acre. 
(b)  For single-family residential lots not served by water and/or sewer, the minimum area shall be as required in section 24-126. The required area for any such use shall be approved by the health official. All other permitted uses shall be served by public water and sewerage systems. 
(Code 1973, § 29-36) 
Sec. 29-149. - Setback. 
    Setbacks in a residential district R-3 shall be located thirty-five (35) feet or more from any street right-of-way which is fifty (50) feet or greater in width or sixty (60) feet or more from the center of any street right-of-way less than fifty (50) feet in width. This shall be known as the "setback line." 
(Code 1973, § 29-37) 
Sec. 29-150. - Frontage. 
    The minimum lot width at the setback line in a residential district R-3 shall be fifty (50) feet, plus fifteen (15) feet for each additional dwelling unit more than one (1). 
(Code 1973, § 29-38) 
Sec. 29-151. - Yards. 
(a)  The minimum side yard for each main structure in a residential district R-3 shall be seven (7) feet or ten (10) percent of lot width but not less than four (4) feet. 
(b)  Each main structure shall have a rear yard of fifteen (15) feet. 
(Code 1973, § 29-39) 
Sec. 29-152. - Height. 
    Structures in a residential district R-3 may be erected up to thirty-five (35) feet in height from grade; except that: 
(1)  The height limit for structures may be increased up to forty-five (45) feet and up to three (3) stories; provided, that each side yard is seven (7) feet, plus one (1) foot of side yard for each additional foot of building height over thirty-five (35) feet. 
(2)  A public or semipublic building, such as a school, church, library or hospital may be erected to a height of seventy (70) feet from grade; provided, that required front, side and rear yards shall be increased one (1) foot for each foot in height over thirty-five (35) feet. 
(3)  College structures may be erected to a height of one hundred twenty-five (125) feet from grade; provided, that required front, side and rear yards shall be increased one (1) foot for each foot in height over thirty-five (35) feet. 
(4)  Church spires, belfries, cupolas, monuments, municipal water towers, chimneys, flues, flagpoles, television antennas and radio aerials are exempt. Parapet walls may be up to four (4) feet above the height of the building on which the walls rest. 
(Code 1973, § 29-40) 
Sec. 29-153. - Corner lots. 
(a)  Of the two (2) sides of a corner lot in a residential district R-3 the front shall be deemed to be the shortest of the two (2) sides fronting on streets. 
(b)  The side yard on the side facing the side street shall be twenty (20) feet or more for both main and accessory buildings. 
(c)  For subdivisions platted after February 18, 1971, each corner lot shall have a minimum width at the setback line of seventy-five (75) feet or more. 
(Code 1973, § 29-41) 
Secs. 29-154-29-170. - Reserved.

DIVISION 7. - RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT R-4 

Sec. 29-196. - Statement of intent. 
    Residential district R-4 encompasses medium-density residential area, both existing and planned. The following regulations are designed to accommodate this type of development. This district should provide a suitable environment for persons who desire a predominantly single-family area where a variety of housing types are permitted. 
(Code 1973, § 29-42; Ord. No. 94, 3-9-2005) 
Sec. 29-197. - Uses. 
    Only one (1) building and its accessory building may be erected on any lot or parcel of land in residential district R-4. Structures to be erected on land to be used shall be for one (1) or more of the following uses: 
(1)  Single-family dwellings. 
(2)  Two-family dwellings or two (2) housekeeping units. 
(3)  Multiple family dwellings with a conditional use permit. 
(4)  Rooming or boarding houses which may accommodate not more than four (4) roomers and/or boarders. 
(5)  Home occupations conducted by the occupant. 
(6)  University related facilities, with a conditional use permit. 
(7)  Churches, lodges, armories and other public and semipublic facilities including hospitals, but excepting veterinary hospitals and hospitals specializing in the care and treatment of mental illnesses, narcotic addicts or alcoholics, unwed mothers and those about to become mothers out of wedlock. A conditional use permit may be required for those uses. 
(8)  Parks and playgrounds of a noncommercial nature. 
(9)  Day schools and kindergartens with conditional use permit. 
(10)  Off-street parking as required by this chapter. 
(11)  Accessory uses and structures customarily incident to any use permitted by this section, such as servants' quarters, greenhouses or workshops; provided, that none shall be conducted for gain and that no accessory buildings shall be inhabited by other than those who are employees of the owner, [lessor] or tenant of the premises. No accessory building may be closer than five (5) feet to any property line. 
(12)  Private garage on the same lot with the building not maintained for the service of the public or operated or conducted for commercial or industrial use, but no such private garage shall be hereafter located or erected on any residential block closer to the street than the setback line for the residence on that street or side street. 
(13)  Private group garages, not exceeding four (4), fronting on alleys; provided, that no commercial repair work is done; further provided, that it must be set back not less than five (5) feet from alley. 
(14)  Public utilities, including poles, lines, distribution transformers, pipes, meters, and other facilities necessary for the provision and maintenance of public utilities, including water and sewerage systems. Electrical transmission lines and substations are excluded. 
(15)  Church bulletin boards and church identification signs for church activities only not exceeding twelve (12) square feet in area. 
(16)  Small professional or announcement signs not exceeding three (3) square feet in area no part of which shall be nearer than one (1) foot to any town property line and nonelectrical temporary real estate signs not over six (6) square feet in area no part of which shall be nearer than five (5) feet from any property line and used only to advertise the premises upon which erected. 
(17)  Condominium and townhouse developments. Overall density shall not exceed ten (10) dwelling units per acre. A conditional use permit shall be required. 
(Code 1973, § 29-43; Ord. of 9-9-98; Ord. No. 62, 3-14-2002; Ord. No. 119, 6-11-2008) 
Sec. 29-198. - Minimum area. 
(a)  The minimum lot area in a residential district R-4 shall be five thousand (5,000) square feet, plus two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet for each additional dwelling unit under one (1) roof for lots served by public water and sewer; however, the overall density shall not exceed ten (10) dwelling units per acre. 
(b)  For lots not served by water and/or sewer, the minimum area shall be as required in section 24-126. The required area for any such use shall be approved by the health official. The administrator may require a greater area if considered necessary by the health official. Private schools must conform to land area requirements of the state board of education. 
(c)  Minimum lot area for townhouses/condominiums shall be at least one thousand (1,000) square feet. 
(Code 1973, § 29-44; Ord. No. 154, 1-9-2013 ) 
Sec. 29-199. - Setback. 
(a)  Setbacks in a residential district R-4 shall be located thirty-five (35) feet or more from any street right-of-way which is fifty (50) feet or greater in width of sixty (60) feet or more from the center of any street right-of-way less than fifty (50) feet in width. This shall be known as the "setback line." 
(b)  Setbacks for townhouses/condominiums shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet from the front, fifteen (15) feet from the rear yard and no side yard. 
(Code 1973, § 29-45; Ord. No. 154, 1-9-2013 ) 
Sec. 29-200. - Frontage. 
(a)  The minimum lot width at the setback line in a residential district R-4 shall be fifty (50) feet. 
(b)  Minimum frontage for townhouses/condominiums shall be twenty (20) feet. 
(Code 1973, § 29-46; Ord. No. 154, 1-9-2013 ) 
Sec. 29-201. - Yards. 
(a)  The minimum side yard for each main structure in a residential district R-4 shall be seven (7) feet or ten (10) percent of lot width but not less than four (4) feet. 
(b)  Each main structure shall have a rear yard of fifteen (15) feet or more. 
(Code 1973, § 29-47) 
Sec. 29-202. - Height. 
    Structures in a residential district R-4 may be erected up to thirty-five (35) feet in height from grade; except, that: 
(1)  The height limit for dwellings may be increased up to forty-five (45) feet and up to three (3) stories; provided, that each side yard is twenty (20) feet, plus one (1) foot or more for each additional foot of building height over thirty-five (35) feet. 
(2)  A public or semipublic building, such as a school, church or library, may be erected to a height of seventy (70) feet from grade; provided, that required front, side and rear yards shall be increased one (1) foot for each foot in height over thirty-five (35) feet. 
(3)  College structures may be erected to a height of one hundred twenty-five (125) feet from grade; provided, that required front, side and rear yards shall be increased one (1) foot for each foot in height over thirty-five (35) feet. 
(4)  Church spires, belfries, cupolas, municipal water towers, chimneys, flues, flagpoles, television antennae and radio aerials are exempt. Parapet walls may be up to four (4) feet above the height of the building on which the walls rest. 
(5)  Accessory buildings over one (1) story in height shall be at least ten (10) feet from any lot line. All accessory buildings shall be less than the main building in height. 
(6)  Townhouses/condominiums may be constructed to a height of forty-five (45) feet from grade. 
(Code 1973, § 29-48; Ord. No. 154, 1-9-2013 ) 
Sec. 29-203. - Corner lots. 
(a)  Of the two (2) sides of a corner lot in a residential district R-4 the front shall be deemed to be the shortest of the two (2) sides fronting on streets. 
(b)  The side yard on the side facing the side street shall be twenty (20) feet or more for both main and accessory buildings. 
(c)  The side yard for townhouse/condominiums on the side facing the side street shall be ten (10) feet or more for both main and accessory buildings. 
(d)  For subdivisions platted after February 18, 1971, each corner lot shall have a minimum width at the setback line of seventy-five (75) feet or more. 
(Code 1973, § 29-49; Ord. No. 154, 1-9-2013 ) 
Secs. 29-204-29-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT R-5 

Sec. 29-221. - Statement of intent. 
    Residential district R-5 is intended to accommodate mobile home parks exclusively. This district is based on the premise that the demand for mobile homes can best be supplied by the designation of one (1) or certainly not more than several mobile home parks. The following regulations are designed to provide an attractive and harmonious environment for mobile home dwellings with all the amenities normally found in a substantial residential neighborhood. 
(Code 1973, § 29-50) 
Sec. 29-222. - Uses. 
    In residential district R-5 structures to be erected or land to be used shall be for some combination of the following uses: 
(1)  Mobile home parks with conditional use permit. 
(2)  Accessory structures. 
(3)  Home occupations conducted by the occupant. 
(4)  Parks and playgrounds. 
(5)  Streets, accessways and off-street parking as required by this chapter. 
(6)  Public utilities, including poles, lines, distribution transformers, pipes, meters and other facilities necessary for the provision and maintenance of public utilities, including water and sewerage. 
(7)  Small professional or announcement signs not exceeding three (3) square feet in area no part of which shall be nearer than one (1) foot to any town property line and nonelectrical temporary real estate signs not over six (6) square feet in area. 
(Code 1973, § 29-51) 
Sec. 29-223. - Minimum area. 
(a)  Minimum size, number of spaces. The minimum area for each mobile home park shall be five (5) acres. Minimum number of spaces completed and ready for occupancy before first occupancy is permitted shall be twenty-five (25). 
(b)  Maximum density of units per acre. The total density of any mobile home park shall not exceed eight (8) units per gross acre. 
(c)  Minimum size per space. The minimum area for an individual mobile home space shall be five thousand (5,000) square feet. 
(d)  Minimum width of space. The minimum average width for each mobile home lot shall be fifty (50) feet; except, that for any mobile home unit greater than twelve (12) feet in width, the minimum average lot width shall be sixty (60) feet. This average shall be maintained between points ten (10) feet in front of the mobile home stand and ten (10) feet to the rear of the stand. 
(Code 1973, § 29-52) 
Sec. 29-224. - Yards. 
(a)  Minimum distance between mobile homes. No mobile home shall be placed within twenty-five (25) feet of another. 
(b)  Yards abutting common areas. The distance from the line or corner of the mobile home stand to a private access drive, a common parking area, a common walk or other common area shall be twenty (20) feet minimum. Patios, carports and individual storage facilities shall be disregarded in determining yard width. 
(Code 1973, § 29-53) 
Sec. 29-225. - Setback. 
    No mobile home shall be placed a lesser distance from the mobile home park boundary than the side yard width required in the zoning district in which the property adjoining each such boundary lies. In no case shall any mobile home be placed less than fifteen (15) feet from the mobile home park boundary. The distance from the line or corner of the mobile home stand to a public street shall be as designated on the setback map or, if the setback is not designated on such map, shall be located thirty-five (35) feet or more from any street right-of-way which is fifty (50) feet or greater in width or sixty (60) feet or more from the center of any street right-of-way less than fifty (50) feet in width. This shall be known as the "setback line." 
(Code 1973, § 29-54) 
Sec. 29-226. - Mobile home stand. 
(a)  Generally. A mobile home stand is part of an individual lot which has been reserved for the placement of the mobile home. 
(b)  Placement. The mobile home stand placement shall provide for the practical placement on and removal from the lot of both the mobile home and its appurtenant structures and the retention of the home on the lot in a stable condition and in satisfactory relationship to its surroundings. 
(c)  Size. The size of the mobile home stand shall be suitable for the general market to be served by the individual proposal and suitable to fit dimensions of mobile homes anticipated, including mobile home appurtenant structures or appendages. 
(d)  Location. The location of each mobile home stand shall be at such elevation, distance and angle in relation to the access street and the mobile home accessway that placement and removal of the mobile home is practical. 
(e)  Construction. The construction of the mobile home stand shall be of appropriate material, properly graded, placed and compacted so as to be durable and adequate for the support of the maximum anticipated loads during all seasons. 
(f)  Gradient. There shall be zero percent of five (5) percent longitudinal gradient and adequate crown or cross gradient for surface drainage. 
(g)  Markers for mobile home lots. Every mobile home lot shall be clearly defined on the ground by permanent markers. There shall be posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on each lot a number corresponding to the number of each lot as shown on the site plan submitted as required in section 29-225 so that each lot may be easily identified. 
(Code 1973, § 29-55) 
Sec. 29-227. - Patios. 
(a)  Required. Each mobile home lot shall provide an appropriate outdoor living space to supplement the limited interior space of a mobile home. 
(b)  Size. The minimum size of each mobile home lot outdoor living space shall be one hundred eighty (180) square feet. 
(c)  Location. Every patio location shall be convenient to the entrance of the mobile home, appropriately related to open areas of the lot and other facilities, fitted to terrain and natural features and related to anticipated mobile home models. 
(d)  Elevation. The patio shall be at an elevation at least as high as the elevation of its mobile home stand. Where topographical conditions permit, the patio and adjoining yard area on the entry side of the mobile home stand may be as much as two (2) feet higher than the mobile home stand in order that the level of the patio and outdoor living areas will be close to the floor level of an in-place mobile home. The grade difference between the patio and the stand may be taken up by a retaining wall or cribbing or by an earth slope. Where the patio is higher than the mobile home stand, adequate surface drainage of the mobile home stand shall be provided across the other side or ends of the stand. There shall be adequate crown or cross gradient for surface drainage. 
(e)  Construction. Any subgrading shall be well-drained, uniformly graded and compacted. Construction shall provide a useful outdoor surface constructed or formed either monolithically or in movable units with weather-resistant materials placed sufficiently close together to create a paved area. 
(Code 1973, § 29-56) 
Sec. 29-228. - Tenant storage. 
(a)  Generally. Tenant storage shall provide storage facilities on or conveniently near each mobile home for the active storage of outdoor equipment, furniture and tools and for the inactive storage of such other material as is used only seasonally or infrequently by the typical tenant and cannot be conveniently stored in the typical mobile home. 
(b)  Size. There shall be a minimum of ninety (90) cubic feet provided for general storage for each mobile home lot. 
(c)  Design and location of storage facilities. Storage facilities shall be provided on the lot or in compounds located within a reasonable distance not more than one hundred (100) feet from each stand located not closer to private streets and public streets than the mobile home unit itself. Storage facilities shall be designed in a manner that will enhance the appearance of the park and shall be constructed of suitable weather-resistant materials appropriate under the use and maintenance contemplated. 
(Code 1973, § 29-57) 
Sec. 29-229. - Streets. 
(a)  General requirements. All streets, both public and private, serving mobile home lots shall conform to the construction standards of the state department of highways. Curbs and gutters are encouraged; however, in the event that they are not provided, paved drainage facilities shall be provided. 
(b)  Pavement widths. Pavements shall be of adequate widths to accommodate the contemplated parking and traffic load in accordance with the type of street, with ten (10) feet minimum for moving lanes, with eight (8) feet minimum land for parallel guest parking and two (2) feet minimum additional width for pedestrian use where adjacent sidewalk is not provided. 
(c)  Alignment and gradient. Streets shall be adapted to the topography and shall have suitable alignment and gradient for safety of traffic, satisfactory surface and groundwater drainage and proper functioning of sanitary and storm sewer systems. 
(d)  Intersections. Street intersections shall generally be at right angles. Offsets at intersections and intersections of more than two (2) streets at one (1) point shall be avoided. 
(e)  Extent of improvements. The street improvements shall extend continuously from the existing improved street system to provide suitable access to the mobile home stands and other important facilities on the property, to provide adequate connections to existing or future streets at the boundaries of the property and to provide convenient circulation of vehicles with origins or destinations on the property. 
(f)  Grading. Grading shall be for the full width of the street to provide suitable finish grades for pavement and any sidewalks with adequate surface drainage and convenient access to the mobile home stands and other important facilities on the property. 
(Code 1973, § 29-58) 
Sec. 29-230. - Walks. 
    Walks shall be provided for safe, convenient, all-season pedestrian access of adequate width for intended use and durable and convenient to maintain. There shall be: 
(1)  Individual walks to each mobile home stand from a paved street or from a paved driveway or parking space connecting to a paved street. 
(2)  Common walks in locations where pedestrian traffic is concentrated, for example, at the court entrance and to the court office and other important facilities. Common walks should preferably be through interior areas removed from the vicinity of streets. 
(3)  Width, alignment and gradient of walks shall be appropriate for safety, convenience and appearance and shall be suitable for use both by pedestrians and for the circulation of small-wheeled vehicles such as baby carriages and service carts. Sudden changes in alignment and gradient should be avoided. 
(4)  Width shall generally be at least three (3) feet for walks on individual lots and at least four (4) feet for common walks. 
(5)  Gradients shall be between one-eighth inch per foot or one (1) percent and five-eighths inch per foot or five (5) percent wherever possible, especially in areas subject to ice conditions. 
(6)  Maximum cross-slope should be one-fourth inch per foot and minimum shall be one-eighth inch per foot or one (1) percent. 
(7)  No required walk shall be used as drainageway. 
(8)  Pavement shall be cement concrete at least four (4) inches in depth. Joints shall be at regular intervals not exceeding twice the width of the walk. The base should be a minimum of four (4) inches thick and shall consist of crushed stone, gravel or other appropriate durable material compacted to maximum practical density. 
(Code 1973, § 29-59) 
Sec. 29-231. - Parking spaces. 
    Parking spaces shall be provided at the rate of at least two (2) car spaces for each mobile home lot. Each such parking space shall be not less than ten (10) feet wide and twenty-two (22) feet deep; shall be surfaced for its entire area with durable, hard material, suitable for all-weather use; and shall have unobstructed access to a public street or common street highway. 
(Code 1973, § 29-60) 
Sec. 29-232. - Water supply. 
    An adequate supply of potable water approved by the health department shall be furnished from a public water supply system or from a private water system conforming to all applicable laws, regulations, resolutions and ordinances, with supply faucets located on each mobile home lot. 
(Code 1973, § 29-61) 
Sec. 29-233. - Sewerage facilities. 
    In each mobile home park all waste or wastewater from a faucet, toilet, tub, shower, sink, slop-sink, drain, washing machine, garbage disposal unit or laundry shall empty into an approved sewer system. The discharge of waste or wastewater into a septic tank is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1973, § 29-62) 
Sec. 29-234. - Garbage and trash disposal. 
    Corrosion-resistive metal garbage cans or other noncombustible containers with tight-fitting covers shall be provided in quantities adequate to permit disposal of all garbage and rubbish. Each mobile home lot shall have at least one (1) garbage can within one hundred (100) feet of it. The cans shall be kept in sanitary condition as determined by inspection of the health department. Garbage and rubbish shall be collected and disposed of as frequently as may be necessary, but not less than twice weekly, at least three (3) days apart, to insure that the garbage cans shall not overflow. 
(Code 1973, § 29-63) 
Sec. 29-235. - Electric lighting and outlets. 
    All entrances, exits and driveways shall be lighted at night. Not less than a one-hundred-watt electric light shall be provided for each two hundred (200) lineal feet of internal driveway and at each entrance and exit to the mobile home park. At least one (1) receptacle outlet for each mobile home space shall be provided; this receptacle and other electric wiring shall conform to the National Electrical Code. 
(Code 1973, § 29-64) 
Sec. 29-236. - Storage tanks. 
(a)  Gasoline, liquefied petroleum, gas or oil storage tanks shall be so installed as to comply with all town, state and national fire prevention code regulations. 
(b)  Where oil heating of a mobile home is provided, an underground storage facility shall be provided in each mobile home lot. In lieu of this, a central storage facility may be constructed to serve the mobile home park. 
(Code 1973, § 29-65) 
Sec. 29-237. - Playgrounds. 
(a)  There shall be provided areas and facilities for recreational purposes appropriate to the needs of the occupants. 
(b)  Each mobile home park shall provide one (1) multiple purpose playground of at least twenty thousand (20,000) square feet, plus two thousand (2,000) square feet for each mobile home space in the mobile home park, to be provided in a convenient location and to consist of one (1) usable contiguous area. If the mobile home park is designated to accommodate over one hundred (100) mobile homes, the required playground area may be provided in two (2) or more locations; provided that the areas are large enough to accommodate normal play activities. 
(Code 1973, § 29-66) 
Sec. 29-238. - Additions to mobile homes. 
    No permanent or semipermanent structure shall be affixed to any mobile home as an addition to such mobile home nor shall any accessory structure be permitted on any mobile home lot or in any mobile home park except those accessory structures required by the chapter and a structure to house an office. If an office structure is provided, its construction shall comply with all applicable laws and ordinances. The prohibition herein against any addition or accessory to a mobile home shall not apply to a canopy or awning designed for use with a mobile home nor to any expansion unit or accessory structure specifically manufactured for mobile homes. The lot coverage of a mobile home, together with an expansion or accessory structure permitted thereto by this chapter, shall not exceed twenty (20) percent of the total mobile home lot area. 
(Code 1973, § 29-67) 
Sec. 29-239. - Height. 
    No mobile home shall exceed fourteen (14) feet in height nor shall any storage facility or other accessory structure exceed the height of any mobile home which it serves. Utilities, television antennas and radio aerials are exempt. 
(Code 1973, § 29-68) 
Sec. 29-240. - Mobile home standards. 
(a)  Every mobile home occupied as a dwelling unit located in the town after the date of the adoption of this chapter shall meet the minimum standards for plumbing, heating and electric systems as defined by the United States Standards Institute Publication A 1119.1. Mobile homes that do not meet these minimum standards for plumbing, heating and electrical systems shall not be issued an occupancy permit by the zoning administrator. 
(b)  The minimum standards for plumbing, heating and electrical systems as defined by the United States Standards Institute Publication A119 (1963), as amended and revised periodically, are hereby made a part of and incorporated by reference into this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 29-69) 
Sec. 29-241. - Requirements for permitted uses. 
    Before a zoning permit shall be issued or construction begun on any permitted use in this district, detailed site plans indicating compliance with the substantive provisions of this chapter shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for study. The administrator may refer these plans to the planning commission for its recommendations. Modifications of the plans may be required. 
(Code 1973, § 29-70) 
Secs. 29-242-29-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - BUSINESS DISTRICT B-1 

Sec. 29-261. - Statement of intent. 
    Business district B-1 is intended to encompass the existing major downtown retailing center. Business district B-1 should provide a framework for a strong nucleus of the business community in which each business can enhance other businesses and where all the amenities and services of downtown can be provided. Since business district B-1 is intended to include only the existing built-up downtown area, off street parking is not required, except as provided for in subsection 29-262(40). 
(Code 1973, § 29-71; Ord. No. 93, 3-9-2005) 
Sec. 29-262. - Uses. 
    In business district B-1 structures to be erected or land to be used shall be for one (1) or more of the following uses: 
(1)  Department stores. 
(2)  Variety stores. 
(3)  Wearing apparel stores. 
(4)  Furniture stores. 
(5)  Household appliance stores. 
(6)  Drugstores. 
(7)  Banks. 
(8)  Jewelry stores. 
(9)  Off-street parking. 
(10)  Hardware stores. 
(11)  Grocery stores. 
(12)  Restaurants. 
(13)  Theaters, assembly halls. 
(14)  Hotels, motels. 
(15)  Clubs and lodges. 
(16)  Churches. 
(17)  Libraries. 
(18)  Professional and public offices. 
(19)  Business offices and display rooms. 
(20)  Billiard parlors and poolrooms. 
(21)  Bowling alleys. 
(22)  Recreation centers. 
(23)  Newspaper printing establishments. 
(24)  Barber and beauty shops. 
(25)  Shops for the repair of bicycles, shoes, locks, guns, electrical equipment and similar commodities. 
(26)  Bakeries. 
(27)  Gift, record and tobacco shops. 
(28)  Bookstores. 
(29)  Magazine and newsstands. 
(30)  Liquor stores. 
(31)  Animal hospital with conditional use permit. 
(32)  Laundries, laundromats and dry cleaners. 
(33)  Transportation terminals, automobile and truck sales, service, storage and repairs. 
(34)  Trade or vocational schools with a conditional use permit. 
(35)  Public utilities including poles, lines, distribution transformers, pipes, meters, and/or facilities necessary for the provision and maintenance of public utilities. Electrical transmission lines and substations are excluded. 
(36)  Business or identification signs. 
(37)  Residence, provided occupant is the principal owner of the building and operator of the business contained within the structure. The residence may not be occupied by any persons other than the immediate family of the owner/operator of the business. Off-street parking is required. 
(38)  Auction barns with a conditional use permit. 
(39)  Secondhand stores including flea market sales, provided such activity is conducted wholly within an enclosed building, meeting all the requirements as set forth in town ordinances and the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(40)  Mixed use commercial and residential use by conversion of existing structure, provided that: 
a.  All applicable local and state codes are strictly complied with in the siting and construction of the structure; 
b.  All residential use must be located on the second story of the building or above, immediately above the street level (not including the basement in any such calculation or use); 
c.  A separate street level entrance must be provided for the residential use; 
d.  Each residential unit must be between seven hundred (700) and fifteen hundred (1,500) square feet in finished habitable space as defined by the current building code (excluding bathrooms, closets, halls, storage, or utility spaces); 
e.  Occupancy density shall insure at least three hundred fifty (350) square feet of finished habitable space per occupant as defined by the current building code (excluding bathrooms, closets, halls, storage, or utility spaces); 
f.  Off-street parking under the legal control of the property owner for which the space is made available must be provided in the amount of one (1) parking space per housing unit up to two (2) bedrooms and one (1) additional space for each additional bedroom or room usable as a bedroom, to include any offsite parking within five hundred (500) feet of site (as opposed to normal requirement of three hundred (300) feet). 
g.  All mixed use structures, as outlined in this subsection (40) of this section, that are over seventy-five (75) percent damaged by fire or other disaster will only be allowed to be built back as a commercial use structure. 
(Code 1973, § 29-72; Ord. No. 81, 1-14-2004) 
Sec. 29-263. - Minimum area. 
    There are no area regulations in a business district B-1, except if permitted uses utilize individual water supply or sewage disposal systems, the required area shall be established by the health official. 
(Code 1973, § 29-73) 
Sec. 29-264. - Setback. 
    Setbacks in a business district B-1 shall be located twenty-five (25) feet or more from the center of any street right-of-way. This shall be known as the "setback line." 
(Code 1973, § 29-74) 
Sec. 29-265. - Frontage and yards. 
    For permitted uses in a business district B-1, the minimum side yard or rear adjoining or adjacent to a residential district shall be twenty-five (25) feet and off-street parking shall be in accordance with the provisions contained herein. Provision must be made for loading and unloading commercial supplies and goods. 
(Code 1973, § 29-75) 
Sec. 29-266. - Height. 
    Buildings in a business district B-1 may be erected up to sixty-five (65) feet in height from grade. Church spires, belfries, cupolas, monuments, cooling towers, municipal water towers, chimneys, flues, flagpoles, television antennas and radio aerials are exempt. Parapet walls may be up to four (4) feet above the height of the building on which the walls rest. 
(Code 1973, § 29-76) 
Sec. 29-267. - Requirements for permitted uses. 
    Before a zoning permit shall be issued or construction begun on any permitted use in a business district B-1, or a permit issued for a new use, detailed site plans indicating compliance with the substantive provision of this chapter and in sufficient detail to show the operations and processes shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for study. The administrator may refer these plans to the planning commission and/or town council for their recommendation. Modification of the plans may be required. 
(Code 1973, § 29-77) 
Secs. 29-268-29-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - BUSINESS DISTRICT B-2 

Sec. 29-286. - Statement of intent. 
    Business district B-2 is intended to encompass the expanding major downtown retailing center and to provide for its orderly expansion. Business district B-2 should provide a framework for the perpetuation of a strong nucleus for the business community in which each business can enhance other businesses and where all the amenities and services of downtown can be provided. 
(Code 1973, § 29-78) 
Sec. 29-287. - Uses. 
    In business district B-2 structures to be erected or land to be used shall be for one (1) or more of the following uses: 
(1)  Department stores. 
(2)  Variety stores. 
(3)  Wearing apparel stores. 
(4)  Furniture stores. 
(5)  Household appliance stores. 
(6)  Drugstores. 
(7)  Banks. 
(8)  Hardware stores. 
(9)  Grocery stores. 
(10)  Restaurants. 
(11)  Theaters, assembly halls. 
(12)  Hotels, motels. 
(13)  Clubs and lodges. 
(14)  Churches. 
(15)  Libraries. 
(16)  Professional and public offices. 
(17)  Business offices and display rooms. 
(18)  Billiard parlors and poolrooms. 
(19)  Bowling alleys. 
(20)  Recreation centers. 
(21)  Newspaper printing establishments. 
(22)  Barber and beauty shops. 
(23)  Shoe repair shops. 
(24)  Bakeries. 
(25)  Gift, record and tobacco shops. 
(26)  Bookstores. 
(27)  Magazine and newsstands. 
(28)  Liquor stores. 
(29)  Animal hospital with conditional use permit. 
(30)  Laundries, laundromats, and dry cleaners. 
(31)  Transportation terminals, automobile and truck sales, service, storage, and repairs. 
(32)  Trade or vocational schools with a conditional use permit. 
(33)  Off-street parking as required by this chapter. 
(34)  Public utilities including poles, lines, distribution transformers, pipes, meters, and/or facilities necessary for the provision and maintenance of public utilities. Electrical transmission lines and substations are excluded. 
(35)  Business or identification signs. 
(36)  Auction barns with a conditional use permit. 
(37)  Secondhand stores, including flea market sales, provided such activity is conducted wholly within an enclosed building, meeting all the requirements as set forth in town ordinances and the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(38)  Mixed use commercial and residential use by conversion of existing structure, provided that: 
a.  All applicable local and state codes are strictly complied with in the siting and construction of the structure; 
b.  All residential use must be located on the second story of the building or above, immediately above the street level (not including the basement in any such calculation or use); 
c.  A separate street level entrance must be provided for the residential use; 
d.  Each residential unit must be between seven hundred (700) and fifteen hundred (1,500) square feet in finished habitable space as defined by the current building code (excluding bathrooms, closets, halls, storage, or utility spaces); 
e.  Occupancy density shall insure at least three hundred fifty (350) square feet of finished habitable space per occupant as defined by the current building code (excluding bathrooms, closets, halls, storage, or utility spaces); 
f.  Off-street parking under the legal control of the property owner for which the space is made available must be provided in the amount of one (1) parking space per housing unit up to two (2) bedrooms and one (1) additional space for each additional bedroom or room usable as a bedroom, to include any offsite parking within five hundred (500) feet of site (as opposed to normal requirement of three hundred (300) feet). 
g.  All mixed use structures, as outlined in this subsection (38) of this section, that are over seventy-five (75) percent damaged by fire or other disaster will only be allowed to be built back as a commercial use structure. 
(39)  Colleges and campus related [dwellings] for up to four (4) persons not related by blood, marriage, adoption, or guardianship per dwelling unit with a conditional use permit. 
(Code 1973, § 29-79; Ord. No. 81, 1-14-2004; Ord. No. 90, 2-1-2005) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90, adopted Feb. 1, 2005, set out provisions intended for use as § 29-287(38). For purposes of classification and to avoid duplicate numbering in this subsection of the Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 29-287(39). 
Sec. 29-288. - Minimum area. 
    There are no area regulations in a business district B-2, except if permitted uses utilize individual water supply or sewage disposal systems, the required area shall be established by the health official. 
(Code 1973, § 29-80) 
Sec. 29-289. - Setback. 
    Setbacks in a business district B-2 shall be located twenty-five (25) feet or more from the center of any street right-of-way. This shall be known as the "setback line." 
(Code 1973, § 29-81) 
Sec. 29-290. - Frontage and yards. 
    For permitted uses in a business district B-2 the minimum side yard or rear yard adjoining or adjacent to a residential district shall be twenty-five (25) feet and off-street parking shall be in accordance with the provisions contained herein. Provision must be made for loading and unloading commercial supplies and goods. 
(Code 1973, § 29-82) 
Sec. 29-291. - Height. 
    Buildings in a business district B-2 may be erected up to sixty-five (65) feet in height from grade. Church spires, belfries, cupolas, monuments, cooling towers, municipal water towers, chimneys, flues, flagpoles, television antennae and radio aerials are exempt. Parapet walls may be up to four (4) feet above the height of the building on which the walls rest. 
(Code 1973, § 29-83) 
Sec. 29-292. - Requirements for permitted uses. 
    Before a zoning permit shall be issued or construction begun on any permitted use in a business district B-2 or a permit issued for a new use, detailed site plans indicating compliance with the substantive provisions of this chapter and in sufficient detail to show the operations and processes shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for study. The administrator may refer these plans to the planning commission and/or town council for their recommendation. Modification of the plans may be required. 
(Code 1973, § 29-84) 
Secs. 29-293-29-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - BUSINESS DISTRICT B-3 

Sec. 29-311. - Statement of intent. 
    Business district B-3 is intended to accommodate general business areas, highway-oriented commercial uses and wholesaling operations which by nature or space requirements do not lend themselves to being concentrated within a centralized shopping area. Business district B-3 recognizes the demand for a variety of commercial land uses which might not be compatible with the land uses in many areas of town. 
(Code 1973, § 29-85) 
Sec. 29-312. - Uses. 
    In business district B-3 structures to be erected or land to be used shall be for one (1) or more of the following uses; a conditional use permit may be required for each use: 
(1)  Gasoline service stations (with major repair under cover). 
(2)  Churches. 
(3)  Restaurants, including drive-in restaurants with conditional use permit, commercial recreational or amusement facilities with conditional use permit. 
(4)  Automobile, truck, mobile home sales, services, storage and repairs. 
(5)  Machinery sales and services. 
(6)  Motels. 
(7)  Building, plumbing, woodworking, wholesaling, air-conditioning, sheet metal, electrical and painting contractors' establishments, offices and display rooms; provided, that any material or supplies in an enclosed area must be arranged so as not to detract from the orderly appearance of the area. 
(8)  Tire recapping and vulcanizing. 
(9)  Funeral homes. 
(10)  Grocery stores. 
(11)  Branch banks. 
(12)  Professional and public offices. 
(13)  Veterinary hospitals with conditional use permit. 
(14)  Furniture stores. 
(15)  Billiard parlors and poolrooms. 
(16)  Printing establishments. 
(17)  Appliance stores. 
(18)  Laundries, laundromats and dry cleaners. 
(19)  Transportation terminals, automobile and truck sales, service, storage and repairs. 
(20)  Trade or vocational school with conditional use permit. 
(21)  Off-street parking as required by this chapter. 
(22)  Public utilities, including poles, lines, distribution transformers, pipes, meters and facilities necessary for the provision and maintenance of public utilities; electrical transmission lines and substations are excluded. 
(23)  Business or identification signs. 
(24)  One (1) single-dwelling unit situated within the existing business structure with two (2) off-street parking spaces provided on the property. 
(25)  Nursing homes, with conditional use permit. 
(26)  Auction barns with a conditional use permit. 
(27)  Secondhand stores including flea market sales, provided such activity is conducted wholly within an enclosed building, meeting all the requirements as set forth in town ordinances and the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(28)  Private or public detention or holding facilities for adult immigrant detainees, with a conditional use permit. 
(29)  Mixed use commercial and residential provided that all residential be located on the second story of the building or above, with a conditional use permit. 
(30)  Domestic violence shelters, with a conditional use permit. 
(Code 1973, § 29-86; Ord. No. 43, 5-14-97; Ord. No. 113, 6-13-2007; Ord. No. 145, 9-14-2011; Ord. No. 149, 11-9-2011; Ord. No. 180 , 1-11-2017) 
Sec. 29-313. - Minimum area. 
    There are no area regulations in a business district B-3, except if permitted uses utilize individual water supply or sewage disposal systems, the required area for any such use shall be established by the health official. 
(Code 1973, § 29-87) 
Sec. 29-314. - Setback. 
    Setbacks in a business district B-3 shall be located twenty-five (25) feet or more from the center of any street right-of-way. This shall be known as the "setback line." 
(Code 1973, § 29-88) 
Sec. 29-315. - Frontage and yards. 
    For permitted uses in a business district B-3 the minimum side yard or rear yard adjoining or adjacent to a residential district shall be twenty-five (25) feet, and off-street parking shall be in accordance with the provision contained herein. Provisions must be made for loading and unloading commercial supplies and goods. 
(Code 1973, § 29-89) 
Sec. 29-316. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 150, adopted Nov. 9, 2011, deleted § 29-316, which pertained to height and derived from the Code of 1973, § 29-90. 
Sec. 29-317. - Requirements for permitted uses. 
    Before a zoning permit shall be issued or construction begun on any permitted use in a business district B-3, or a permit issued for a new use, detailed site plans indicating compliance with the substantive provisions of this chapter and in sufficient detail to show the operations and processes shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for study. The administrator may refer these plans to the planning commission and/or town council for their recommendations. Conditional use permit may be required. Modification of the plans may be required. 
(Code 1973, § 29-91) 
Secs. 29-318-29-335. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - BUSINESS DISTRICT B-4 

Sec. 29-336. - Statement of intent. 
    Business district B-4 is intended to accommodate shopping facilities which can supply the needs of families living in the immediate area. At the same time, business district B-4 is intended to be relatively free of the nuisance effects which businesses can render on adjacent residential areas. For this reason only limited types of businesses are allowed with a conditional use permit to insure that the business area is most compatible with adjacent residential areas. 
(Code 1973, § 29-92) 
Sec. 29-337. - Uses. 
    In business district B-4, structures to be erected or land to be used shall be for one (1) or more of the following uses. A conditional use permit may be required for each use. 
(1)  Hotel/motel. 
(2)  University related facilities, with a conditional use permit. 
(3)  Elementary, intermediate and secondary schools, both public and private, with a conditional use permit. 
(4)  Day schools and kindergartens with conditional use permit. 
(5)  Churches, lodges, armories and other public and semipublic facilities, including hospitals, excepting veterinary hospitals and hospitals specializing in the care and treatment of mental illnesses, narcotic addicts or alcoholics, unwed mothers and those about to become mothers out of wedlock. A conditional use permit may be required for these uses. 
(6)  Rest, convalescent or nursing homes but not penal or mental institutions. 
(7)  Parks and playgrounds. 
(8)  Grocery stores. 
(9)  Drugstores. 
(10)  Department stores. 
(11)  Variety stores. 
(12)  Hardware stores. 
(13)  Home shops. 
(14)  Auto supply stores. 
(15)  Laundries, laundromats and dry cleaners. 
(16)  Barber and beauty shops. 
(17)  Professional offices. 
(18)  Branch banks. 
(19)  Shoe repair shops. 
(20)  Restaurants. 
(21)  Bakeries. 
(22)  Gift, record and tobacco shops. 
(23)  Bookstores. 
(24)  Magazine and newsstands. 
(25)  Household furnishings and appliance stores. 
(26)  Off-street parking as required by this chapter. 
(27)  Public utilities, including poles, lines, distribution transformers, pipes, meters and/or facilities necessary for the provision and maintenance of public utilities, including water and sewerage facilities. Electrical transmission lines and substations are excluded. 
(28)  Business or identification signs. 
(29)  Apartment, condominium and townhouse development. Overall density shall not exceed ten (10) dwelling units per acre. A conditional use permit shall be required. 
(30)  Church bulletin boards and church identification signs for church activities, only not exceeding twelve (12) square feet in area no part of which shall be nearer than five (5) feet to any town property line. 
(31)  Temporary real estate signs not over six (6) square feet in area, no part of which shall be nearer than five (5) feet to any property line, and used only to advertise the premises upon which erected. 
(32)  Recreation facilities. 
(33)  Funeral homes with a minimum of twenty (20) parking spaces. 
(34)  Secondhand stores including flea market sales, provided such activity is conducted wholly within an enclosed building. 
(35)  Gas station. 
(Code 1973, § 29-93; Ord. No. 119, 6-11-2008; Ord. No. 154, 1-9-2013 ; Ord. No. 170 , 3-11-2015; Ord. No. 4-2015 , 4-8-2015; Ord. No. 171 , 11-12-2015) 
Sec. 29-338. - Minimum area. 
    There are no area regulations in a business district B-4, except for permitted uses utilizing individual water supply or sewage disposal systems, the required area use shall be established by the health official. 
(Code 1973, § 29-94; Ord. No. 140, 6-11-2008) 
Sec. 29-339. - Setback. 
    Setbacks in a business district B-4 shall be located thirty (30) feet or more from any street right-of-way which is fifty (50) feet or greater in width or sixty (60) feet or more from the centerline of any street right-of-way less than fifty (50) feet in width; except, that signs advertising sale or rent of premises may be erected up to the property line. This shall be known as the "setback line." 
(Code 1973, § 29-95) 
Sec. 29-340. - Frontage and yards. 
    For permitted uses in a business district B-4 the minimum side yard adjoining or adjacent to a residential district shall be twenty-five (25) feet or more and off-street parking shall be in accordance with the provisions contained herein. 
(Code 1973, § 29-96; Ord. No. 140, 6-11-2008) 
Sec. 29-341. - Reserved.

Sec. 29-342. - Requirements for permitted uses. 
    Before a zoning permit shall be issued or construction begun on any permitted use in a business district B-4, or a permit issued for a new use, detailed site plans indicating compliance with the substantive provisions of this chapter and in sufficient detail to show the operations and processes shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for study. The administrator may refer these plans to the planning commission and/or town council for their recommendations. Modification of the plans may be required. 
(Code 1973, § 29-98)
